chunks.content: Enables you to perform Active Directory account-related activities. :::note For additional information about Active Directory accounts, refer to [LINK] ::: import DocCardList from '@theme/DocCardList'; <DocCardList />
chunks.originalContent:
Enables you to perform Active Directory account-related activities.

:::note
For additional information about Active Directory accounts, refer to [Managing Users](../../../Product-Navigation/Repository/Recipients/Managing-Users.mdx)
:::

chunks.content: Retrieves the last date in which a selected machine logged in to the Active Directory.
chunks.originalContent: Retrieves the last date in which a selected machine logged in to the Active Directory.
chunks.pageTitle: AD Computer Last Logged In Date

chunks.content: Date (by the default operating system's regional setting format).
chunks.originalContent: Date (by the default operating system's regional setting format).
chunks.pageTitle: AD Computer Last Logged In Date

chunks.content: * **Computer Name** – The computer that logged in to the Active Directory (e.g., `Austin HQ`). :::note The selected computer must be defined as a Device in VAR::PRODUCT_FULL. ::: * **Host Name** – The name or IP address of the Active Directory's server. * **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field. * **Port** – The port through which we connect to Active Directory. Port 389 is the default unsecured port. Port 636 is the pre-defined secured port. You may enter any other accessible port here.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Computer Name** – The computer that logged in to the Active Directory (e.g., `Austin HQ`).  
  :::note
  The selected computer must be defined as a Device in VAR::PRODUCT_FULL.
  :::
* **Host Name** – The name or IP address of the Active Directory's server.
* **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
* **Port** – The port through which we connect to Active Directory. Port 389 is the default unsecured port. Port 636 is the pre-defined secured port. You may enter any other accessible port here.
chunks.pageTitle: AD Computer Last Logged In Date

chunks.content: Copies an Active Directory user account and sets its properties.
chunks.originalContent: Copies an Active Directory user account and sets its properties.

chunks.content: Success (account copied) /Failure.
chunks.originalContent: Success (account copied) /Failure.

chunks.content: * **Account Name** – The name of the user account you want to copy (e.g., `jsmith`). * **Host Name** – The hostname or IP address of the Active Directory server. * **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field. * **Port** – The port through which we connect to Active Directory. Port 389 is the default unsecured port. Port 636 is the pre-defined secured port. You may enter any other accessible port here. * **First Name** – The new user's first name (e.g., `Michael`). * **Initials** – The first and last names’ initials. * **Last Name** – The new user's last name (e.g., `Parker`). * **Full Name** – The new user's full name (e.g., `Michael Parker`). * **Login Name** – The new user's selected login name (e.g., `mparker`). * **Login Password** – The new user's selected login password. * **Email** – The new user's email address. * **User must change password at next login** – Determines whether or not to require the user to change the password upon login. * **Password never expires** – Determines whether the user's password ever expires. * **Additional Properties** – Any additional Active Directory property you may wish to apply to the user.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Account Name** – The name of the user account you want to copy (e.g., `jsmith`).
* **Host Name** – The hostname or IP address of the Active Directory server.
* **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
* **Port** – The port through which we connect to Active Directory. Port 389 is the default unsecured port. Port 636 is the pre-defined secured port. You may enter any other accessible port here.
* **First Name** – The new user's first name (e.g., `Michael`).
* **Initials** – The first and last names’ initials.
* **Last Name** – The new user's last name (e.g., `Parker`).
* **Full Name** – The new user's full name (e.g., `Michael Parker`).
* **Login Name** – The new user's selected login name (e.g., `mparker`).
* **Login Password** – The new user's selected login password.
* **Email** – The new user's email address.
* **User must change password at next login** – Determines whether or not to require the user to change the password upon login.
* **Password never expires** – Determines whether the user's password ever expires.
* **Additional Properties** – Any additional Active Directory property you may wish to apply to the user.

chunks.content: Creates a new account in the Active Directory.
chunks.originalContent: Creates a new account in the Active Directory.

chunks.content: Success (account created) /Failure
chunks.originalContent: Success (account created) /Failure

chunks.content: * **First name** – User's first name (e.g. `John`). * **Last name** – User's last name (e.g. `Smith`). * **Initials** – The first and last names’ initials. * **Full name** – The new user's full name (e.g., `John Smith`). * **Email** – The new user's email address. * **Login Name** – the new user's login name (e.g., `JSmith`). :::note Active Directory users created by VAR::PRODUCT hold the Login Name (rather than the Full Name) in the Name field in the Active Directory. ::: * **Login Password** – The new user's selected login password. * **Path** – The path of the group to which the new user account is assigned (e.g., `\US\Users`) The path may follow the following conventions: * `OU=<OU Name1>, OU=<Name2>` * `<OU Name1>\<OU Name2>` * `/<OU Name1>/<OU Name2>` * `\` * Type in `all` or `\` to scan the entire Active Directory. * **Host Name** – The name or IP address of the Active Directory's server. * **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field. * **User must change password at next login** – Determines whether or not to require the user to change the password upon login. * **Password never expires** – Determines whether the user's password ever expires. * **Port** – The port through which we connect to Active Directory. Port 389 is the default unsecured port. Port 636 is the pre-defined secured port. You may enter any other accessible port here.
chunks.originalContent:
* **First name** – User's first name (e.g. `John`).
* **Last name** – User's last name (e.g. `Smith`).
* **Initials** – The first and last names’ initials.
* **Full name** – The new user's full name (e.g., `John Smith`).
* **Email** – The new user's email address.
* **Login Name** – the new user's login name (e.g., `JSmith`).  
  :::note  
  Active Directory users created by VAR::PRODUCT hold the Login Name (rather than the Full Name) in the Name field in the Active Directory.
  :::
* **Login Password** – The new user's selected login password.
* **Path** – The path of the group to which the new user account is assigned (e.g., `\US\Users`)  
   The path may follow the following conventions:
    * `OU=<OU Name1>, OU=<Name2>`
    * `<OU Name1>\<OU Name2>`
    * `/<OU Name1>/<OU Name2>`
    * `\`
    * Type in `all` or `\` to scan the entire Active Directory.
* **Host Name** – The name or IP address of the Active Directory's server.
* **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
* **User must change password at next login** – Determines whether or not to require the user to change the password upon login.
* **Password never expires** – Determines whether the user's password ever expires.
* **Port** – The port through which we connect to Active Directory. Port 389 is the default unsecured port. Port 636 is the pre-defined secured port. You may enter any other accessible port here.

chunks.content: * **Account Type** – The account's type (user/computer). * **Account Name** – The account name (e.g., `John`). * **Host Name** – The name or IP address of the Active Directory's server. * **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field. * **Property Name** – The queried property (e.g., `Employee ID`). :::note The list of properties in this field is not discovered automatically; it is preset with default values. To use a property that does not exist in the list, type in the actual name of the property as it exists in Active Directory (not the display name). :::
chunks.originalContent:
* **Account Type** – The account's type (user/computer).

* **Host Name** – The name or IP address of the Active Directory's server.
* **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
* **Property Name** – The queried property (e.g., `Employee ID`).  
:::note  
The list of properties in this field is not discovered automatically; it is preset with default values. To use a property that does not exist in the list, type in the actual name of the property as it exists in Active Directory (not the display name).
:::

chunks.content: :::note Active Directory Activities allow you to manage your Active Directory accounts (e.g., creating user accounts, deleting user accounts, changing the attributes of a user account or a group). ::: In order to execute Active Directory activities, the following ports must be open between Resolve Actions and the Active Directory server: * Port 389 – LDAP * Port 445 – NTLM
chunks.originalContent:
:::note
Active Directory Activities allow you to manage your Active Directory accounts (e.g., creating user accounts, deleting user accounts, changing the attributes of a user account or a group).
:::

In order to execute Active Directory activities, the following ports must be open between Resolve Actions and the Active Directory server:

* Port 389 – LDAP
* Port 445 – NTLM

chunks.content: Queries the Active Directory using an LDAP Query.

chunks.content: ResultSet.
chunks.originalContent: ResultSet.

chunks.content: * **Domain** – The Active Directory's domain. Example: `mddc.com` :::note If the Domain field is left empty, the default domain is selected. ::: * **Path** – The group's location in the Active Directory's hierarchy (e.g., `US\Users`). :::note If the Path field is left empty, the default path is selected. ::: * **Query** – The LDAP query's text (e.g., `(givenname=J*)`. * **Properties** – The properties (of the Active Directory's entities that match the query's criteria) to return. :::note If the Properties field is left empty, all properties of the matching entities are returned. ::: * **Search Scope** – The level of search to perform.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Domain** – The Active Directory's domain.  
  Example: `mddc.com`  
  :::note
  If the Domain field is left empty, the default domain is selected.
  :::
* **Path** – The group's location in the Active Directory's hierarchy (e.g., `US\Users`).
  :::note
  If the Path field is left empty, the default path is selected.
  :::
* **Query** – The LDAP query's text (e.g., `(givenname=J*)`.
* **Properties** – The properties (of the Active Directory's entities that match the query's criteria) to return.  
  :::note
  If the Properties field is left empty, all properties of the matching entities are returned.
  :::
* **Search Scope** – The level of search to perform.

chunks.content: * **Recursive** – Check to list all sub-OUs within and OU. * **Path** – The path of the group to which the new user account is assigned (e.g., `\US\Users`) The path can follow the following conventions: * `OU=<OU Name1>, OU=<Name2>` * `<OU Name1>\<OU Name2>` * `/<OU Name1>/<OU Name2>` * `\` * Type in `all` to scan the entire Active Directory. * **Filter** – The criteria of the listed OUs. * **Host Name** – The host name or IP address of the Active Directory's server. * **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Recursive** – Check to list all sub-OUs within and OU.
* **Path** – The path of the group to which the new user account is assigned (e.g., `\US\Users`)  
   The path can follow the following conventions:
   * `OU=<OU Name1>, OU=<Name2>`
   * `<OU Name1>\<OU Name2>`
   * `/<OU Name1>/<OU Name2>`
   * `\`
   * Type in `all` to scan the entire Active Directory.
* **Filter** – The criteria of the listed OUs.
* **Host Name** – The host name or IP address of the Active Directory's server.
* **User Name** – If required, the user name of an account that has read-write access to the Active Directory.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.

chunks.content: Synchronizes A users/groups and their data with the Actions user list. The activity imports OUs, Groups, and Users information from Active Directory into Actions. :::note You may use the "AD Users Synchronization" template (residing under the Active Directory category) instead of creating it from scratch. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Synchronizes A users/groups and their data with the Actions user list. The activity imports OUs, Groups, and Users information from Active Directory into Actions.

:::note
You may use the "AD Users Synchronization" template (residing under the Active Directory category) instead of creating it from scratch.
:::

chunks.content: Success / Failure.
chunks.originalContent: Success / Failure.

chunks.content: * **Domain** – The domain to which the users belong. * **AD Users** – The table from which to import the users, e.g. `%ADSyncTable%`. * **Update existing** – By default, if a user or a group already exists in Actions (created manually before synchronization), they will not be updated. When this is checked, existing users are updated. * **Create New** – When this checkbox is checked existing users are created. * **Recursive groups** – When a group is synchronized you may decide whether to synchronize the data recursively or not. When synchronizing the data recursively, sub-groups and user data are also synchronized. * **Recursive OUs** – When an OU is synchronized you may decide whether to synchronize the data recursively or not. When synchronizing the data recursively, user data in sub-OUs is also synchronized. * **Field Mapping** – A mapping of the Actions property to the AD property.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Domain** – The domain to which the users belong.
* **AD Users** – The table from which to import the users, e.g. `%ADSyncTable%`.
* **Update existing** – By default, if a user or a group already exists in Actions (created manually before synchronization), they will not be updated. When this is checked, existing users are updated.
* **Create New** – When this checkbox is checked existing users are created.
* **Recursive groups** – When a group is synchronized you may decide whether to synchronize the data recursively or not. When synchronizing the data recursively, sub-groups and user data are also synchronized.
* **Recursive OUs** – When an OU is synchronized you may decide whether to synchronize the data recursively or not. When synchronizing the data recursively, user data in sub-OUs is also synchronized.
* **Field Mapping** – A mapping of the Actions property to the AD property.

chunks.content: * **Module Name** – The name of the AWS module to be used. * **Region** – The region in which the instance resides. * **Image Name/Id** – The image that belongs to the connected Access Key. In the Amazon Console these are under Images > AMIs > AMI ID /AMI name. * **Key Pair Name** – They key pair to be used. In the Amazon Console go to Network & Security > Key Pairs > administratorNG. * **Group Name/Id** – The Name or ID of the group. In the Amazon Console these are under Network & Security > Security Group > Group Name (VAR::PRODUCT_FULL Default). * **Instance Type** – The type of instance to launch, select from the drop-down list. M1small (for example). * **Override Connection Parameters** – Used to launch a new instance using a different AWS account, instead of the original default account saved under the AWS module. * **Access Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different access key here. * **Secret Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different secret key here. * **Token** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different token here.

chunks.content: * **Module Name** – The name of the AWS module to be used. * **Region** – The region in which the instance resides. Example: `ap-northeast-1` * **Instance Name/Id** – The name or ID of the instance. Example: `i-1234567890abcdef0` * **Volume Name/Id** – The name or ID of the EBS volume to attach. The volume and instance must be within the same Availability Zone. Example: `vol-1234567890abcdef0` * **Device Name** – Refers to the instance's Root Device property. This needs to be set with the device name mapping; for example, the mapping for a Windows server is xvdf. Example: `/dev/sdf` * **Override Connection Parameters** – Used to attach an existing volume to an instance on a different AWS account, instead of the original default account saved under the AWS module. * **Action Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different access key here. * **Secret Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different secret key here. * **Token** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different token here.

* **Region** – The region in which the instance resides.  
   Example: `ap-northeast-1`

   Example: `i-1234567890abcdef0`
* **Volume Name/Id** – The name or ID of the EBS volume to attach. The volume and instance must be within the same Availability Zone.  
   Example: `vol-1234567890abcdef0`
* **Device Name** – Refers to the instance's Root Device property. This needs to be set with the device name mapping; for example, the mapping for a Windows server is xvdf.

chunks.content: Creates a new Amazon Web Service volume.
chunks.originalContent: Creates a new Amazon Web Service volume.

chunks.content: The ID of the new volume.
chunks.originalContent: The ID of the new volume.

chunks.content: * **Module Name** – The name of the AWS module to be used. * **Region** – The region in which the instance resides. Example: `ap-northeast-1` * **Snapshot Name/Id** – The snapshot name or ID from which to create the volume. * **Availability Zone** – The Availability Zone in which to create the volume. Example: `us-east-1a` * **Volume Type** – The volume type can be gp2 for General Purpose SSD, io1 for Provisioned IOPS SSD, st1 for Throughput Optimized HDD, sc1 for Cold HDD, or standard for Magnetic volumes. If no volume type is specified, the default is standard in us-east-1, eu-west-1, eu-central-1, us-west-2, us-west-1, sa-east-1, ap-northeast-1, ap-northeast-2, ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2, ap-south-1, us-gov-west-1, and cn-north-1. In all other Regions, EBS defaults to gp2. * **Size (GB)** – The size of the volume, in GiBs. * **IO per Second** – The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) to provision for the volume, with a maximum ratio of 50 IOPS/GiB. Range is 100 to 64,000 IOPS for volumes in most Regions. Maximum IOPS of 64,000 is guaranteed only on Nitro-based instances. Other instance families guarantee performance up to 32,000 IOPS. For more information, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide. * **Encrypted** – Specifies whether the volume should be encrypted. The effect of setting the encryption state to truedepends on the volume origin (new or from a snapshot), starting encryption state, ownership, and whether encryption by default is enabled. For more information, see Encryption by Default in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide. * **KMS Key Id** – The identifier of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) to use for Amazon EBS encryption. If this parameter is not specified, your AWS managed CMK for EBS is used. If KmsKeyId is specified, the encrypted state must be true. * **Override Connection Parameters** – Used to create a new volume on a different AWS account, instead of the original default account saved under the AWS module. * **Access Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different access key here. * **Secret Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different secret key here. * **Token** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different token here.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Module Name** – The name of the AWS module to be used.
* **Region** – The region in which the instance resides.  
   Example: `ap-northeast-1`
* **Snapshot Name/Id** – The snapshot name or ID from which to create the volume.
* **Availability Zone** – The Availability Zone in which to create the volume.  
   Example: `us-east-1a`
* **Volume Type** – The volume type can be gp2 for General Purpose SSD, io1 for Provisioned IOPS SSD, st1 for Throughput Optimized HDD, sc1 for Cold HDD, or standard for Magnetic volumes. If no volume type is specified, the default is standard in us-east-1, eu-west-1, eu-central-1, us-west-2, us-west-1, sa-east-1, ap-northeast-1, ap-northeast-2, ap-southeast-1, ap-southeast-2, ap-south-1, us-gov-west-1, and cn-north-1. In all other Regions, EBS defaults to gp2.
* **Size (GB)** – The size of the volume, in GiBs.
* **IO per Second** – The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) to provision for the volume, with a maximum ratio of 50 IOPS/GiB. Range is 100 to 64,000 IOPS for volumes in most Regions. Maximum IOPS of 64,000 is guaranteed only on Nitro-based instances. Other instance families guarantee performance up to 32,000 IOPS. For more information, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.
* **Encrypted** – Specifies whether the volume should be encrypted. The effect of setting the encryption state to truedepends on the volume origin (new or from a snapshot), starting encryption state, ownership, and whether encryption by default is enabled. For more information, see Encryption by Default in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.
* **KMS Key Id** – The identifier of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) to use for Amazon EBS encryption. If this parameter is not specified, your AWS managed CMK for EBS is used. If KmsKeyId is specified, the encrypted state must be true.
* **Override Connection Parameters** – Used to create a new volume on a different AWS account, instead of the original default account saved under the AWS module.
* **Access Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different access key here.
* **Secret Key** – If overriding the connection parameters set at the module level, enter a different secret key here.

chunks.content: Azure activities integrate with your Azure AD portal.
chunks.originalContent: Azure activities integrate with your Azure AD portal.

chunks.content: Synchronizes Azure AD users/groups and their data with the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL recipients list. The activity imports Groups' and Users' information from Azure AD into Actions.
chunks.originalContent: Synchronizes Azure AD users/groups and their data with the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL recipients list. The activity imports Groups' and Users' information from Azure AD into Actions.

chunks.content: Success / Failure.
chunks.originalContent: Success / Failure.

chunks.content: * **Username** – Username of an administrator account that will be accessing the Azure portal to sync users into * **Password** – The password associated with the account used above. * **App Client ID** – The App Client ID associated with the Azure AD where the users reside. * **AD Users** – The list of AD users/groups to synchronize. This can be static (the object ID for a single user and/or group) or a reference to a memory table created for this purpose. An example memory table is shown below. Example: `%AzureID%` * **Update Existing** – By default, if a user or a group already exists in Actions (created manually before synchronization), they will not be updated. When this is checked, existing users are updated. * **Recursive Groups** – When a group is synchronized you may decide whether to synchronize the data recursively or not. When synchronizing the data recursively, sub-groups and user data are also synchronized. :::note The fields that will be synced from Azure AD to Resolve Actions are: Username, First Name, Last Name, Email, and Mobile Phone. Username, First Name, and Last Name are required. Email and Mobile Phone are highly recommended to contact recipients once they've been synced into Resolve Actions. :::
chunks.originalContent:
* **Username** – Username of an administrator account that will be accessing the Azure portal to sync users into
* **Password** – The password associated with the account used above.
* **App Client ID** – The App Client ID associated with the Azure AD where the users reside.
* **AD Users** – The list of AD users/groups to synchronize. This can be static (the object ID for a single user and/or group) or a reference to a memory table created for this purpose. An example memory table is shown below.  
   Example: `%AzureID%`
* **Update Existing** – By default, if a user or a group already exists in Actions (created manually before synchronization), they will not be updated. When this is checked, existing users are updated.
* **Recursive Groups** – When a group is synchronized you may decide whether to synchronize the data recursively or not. When synchronizing the data recursively, sub-groups and user data are also synchronized.

:::note
The fields that will be synced from Azure AD to Resolve Actions are: Username, First Name, Last Name, Email, and Mobile Phone.

Username, First Name, and Last Name are required. Email and Mobile Phone are highly recommended to contact recipients once they've been synced into Resolve Actions.
:::

chunks.content: Communication Activities are used to notify (deliver information, ask questions, request approval) or assign a person or a group of people to handle the event or Incident that triggered the workflow. Recipients may be contacted via email, SMS or instant messaging.
chunks.originalContent: Communication Activities are used to notify (deliver information, ask questions, request approval) or assign a person or a group of people to handle the event or Incident that triggered the workflow. Recipients may be contacted via email, SMS or instant messaging.

chunks.content: Advanced Communicate Activity is used to assign a person to handle the event or the Incident that triggered the Workflow. It contacts all the recipients in the list, one by one, until one of them takes responsibility for the Incident that triggered the Workflow and is assigned to handle it. The person who takes responsibility for the Incident is displayed in the NG Dashboard under the Incident. Advanced Communicate Activity is similar to Communicate Activity, only each setting parameter of the Activity may also be a Variable.
chunks.originalContent: Advanced Communicate Activity is used to assign a person to handle the event or the Incident that triggered the Workflow. It contacts all the recipients in the list, one by one, until one of them takes responsibility for the Incident that triggered the Workflow and is assigned to handle it. The person who takes responsibility for the Incident is displayed in the NG Dashboard under the Incident. Advanced Communicate Activity is similar to Communicate Activity, only each setting parameter of the Activity may also be a Variable.

chunks.content: * `%communicate.username%`: the name of the user who took responsibility for the Incident. * `%communicate.userfullname%`: the full name of the user who took responsibility for the incident.
chunks.originalContent:
* `%communicate.username%`: the name of the user who took responsibility for the Incident.
* `%communicate.userfullname%`: the full name of the user who took responsibility for the incident.

chunks.content: * **Email Module** – (Only applicable if **Channel** is set to **Email** or **All**) Select the module instance that will provide the email functionality. Do either of the following: * Select the module instance from the drop-down list. :::note Only module instances that you have [LINK] to appear in the list. ::: * Enter a reference to a variable (like `%moduleName%`) that contains the module instance name. In case the variable value is empty, the activity attempts to use the default module instance of that type. If the value is not an actual instance name, the activity returns an error. :::caution Passing a module instance name as a variable allows the use of any module instance even if it doesn't give write permissions to the current user. ::: * **Single message** – determines whether all recipients get the same message or each of them is contacted with an individually defined message. * **Notify all recipients upon assignment** – notifies all recipients that had already been contacted (including the one assigned to the Incident) upon user assignment. * **Message**: * **Message Type** – the type of message sent to the recipient: * **Original** – the message that triggered the Workflow. * **Custom** – any entered free text. * **Template** – a predefined message. * **Template Name** – the selected message template. :::note Message templates are created via VAR::PRODUCT_FULL General Repository. For additional information on message templates, refer to the [LINK]. ::: * **Notifications Steps**: * **Type** – determines whether to contact a specific User, a group of users, or a variable type. :::note If no groups are peresent in Actions, the **Group** option is not available in the table. ::: :::note To use a variable that represents the type of contact (Group/User) use the following convention: `%Type%` (e.g., `%UserType%`). In this case the value is derived from a variable set in Memory Set Activity, as depicted in the following image: [IMAGE] ::: * **Name** – the name of the User/Group or the name of the variable representing one of the options (e.g., `%UserType%`). * **Chanel** – the means of communication by which the recipient is contacted: **Email**, **SMS**, or **All** (for both email and SMS). :::note To use a variable that represents the communication method use the following convention: `%Type%` (e.g., `%email%`). ::: * **Reply Time** – the time frame in which the current recipient may respond and after which escalation is performed and the next recipient is contacted to handle the Incident. :::note To use a variable that represents the Reply Time value use the following convention: `%Type%` (e.g., `%replyTime%`). ::: * **Advanced Options**: * **Time Frame** – the time in the day in which the selected recipient may be contacted.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Email Module** – (Only applicable if **Channel** is set to **Email** or **All**) Select the module instance that will provide the email functionality. Do either of the following:
   * Select the module instance from the drop-down list.
     :::note
     Only module instances that you have [write access](../../Product-Navigation/Configuration/Integrations-and-Modules/access-control-on-integrations-and-modules.mdx) to appear in the list.
     :::
   * Enter a reference to a variable (like `%moduleName%`) that contains the module instance name.  
     In case the variable value is empty, the activity attempts to use the default module instance of that type. If the value is not an actual instance name, the activity returns an error.
     :::caution
     Passing a module instance name as a variable allows the use of any module instance even if it doesn't give write permissions to the current user.
     :::
* **Single message** – determines whether all recipients get the same message or each of them is contacted with an individually defined message.
* **Notify all recipients upon assignment** – notifies all recipients that had already been contacted (including the one assigned to the Incident) upon user assignment.
* **Message**:
   * **Message Type** – the type of message sent to the recipient:  
      * **Original** – the message that triggered the Workflow.  
      * **Custom** – any entered free text.  
      * **Template** – a predefined message.
   * **Template Name** – the selected message template.  
     :::note
     Message templates are created via VAR::PRODUCT_FULL General Repository. For additional information on message templates, refer to the [Message Templates](../../Product-Navigation/Repository/General/Message-Templates.mdx).
     :::
* **Notifications Steps**:
   * **Type** – determines whether to contact a specific User, a group of users, or a variable type.  
   :::note
   If no groups are peresent in Actions, the **Group** option is not available in the table.
   :::
   :::note
   To use a variable that represents the type of contact (Group/User) use the following convention: `%Type%` (e.g., `%UserType%`). In this case the value is derived from a variable set in Memory Set Activity, as depicted in the following image:  
   ![](img/163a30d84618c9.png)
   :::
   * **Name** – the name of the User/Group or the name of the variable representing one of the options (e.g., `%UserType%`).
   * **Chanel** – the means of communication by which the recipient is contacted: **Email**, **SMS**, or **All** (for both email and SMS).
   :::note
   To use a variable that represents the communication method use the following convention: `%Type%` (e.g., `%email%`).
   :::
   * **Reply Time** – the time frame in which the current recipient may respond and after which escalation is performed and the next recipient is contacted to handle the Incident.  
   :::note
   To use a variable that represents the Reply Time value use the following convention: `%Type%` (e.g., `%replyTime%`).
   :::
   * **Advanced Options**:
      * **Time Frame** – the time in the day in which the selected recipient may be contacted.

chunks.content: Contacts the latest recipient who took responsibility for the Workflow, via any former communication Activity.
chunks.originalContent: Contacts the latest recipient who took responsibility for the Workflow, via any former communication Activity.

chunks.content: * **Message Type –** The type of message sent to the recipient: * **Original** – The message that triggered the Workflow. * **Custom** – Any entered free text. * **Template** – A predefined message. :::note Message templates are created via the General page of the Repository section. ::: * **Template Name** – Sends a predefined message template * **Send Recovery Notification –** Sends a notification to the recipient.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Message Type –** The type of message sent to the recipient:  
   * **Original** – The message that triggered the Workflow.  
   * **Custom** – Any entered free text.  
   * **Template** – A predefined message.    
   :::note
   Message templates are created via the General page of the Repository section.
   :::
* **Template Name** – Sends a predefined message template
* **Send Recovery Notification –** Sends a notification to the recipient.

chunks.content: Sends an email to a User, a Group, or a Last Response.
chunks.originalContent: Sends an email to a User, a Group, or a Last Response.

chunks.content: * **Module Name** – Select the module instance that will provide the email functionality. Do either of the following: * Select the module instance from the drop-down list. :::note Only module instances that you have [LINK] to appear in the list. ::: * Enter a reference to a variable (like `%moduleName%`) that contains the module instance name. In case the variable value is empty, the activity attempts to use the default module instance of that type. If the value is not an actual instance name, the activity returns an error. :::caution Passing a module instance name as a variable allows the use of any module instance even if it doesn't give write permissions to the current user. ::: * **"To" Destination Type** – The email's recipient/s. * **"CC" Destination Type** – The email's CC recipient/s. * **User** – A specific User in Actions Recipients Repository. * **Group** – All Users in a Group. * **Last Response** – The recipient who took responsibility for the Incident that triggered the Workflow. :::note You can add multiple email addresses in the following convention: `<address1>;<address2>`. ::: :::note You cannot create or edit users within an activity. User configuration must be managed within the users area. ::: * **Message Type** – The type of message sent to the recipient/s via email: * **Original** – The message that triggered the Workflow. * **Custom** – Any entered free text. * **Template** – A predefined message. :::note Message templates are created via the General page of the Repository section. ::: * **Subject** – The subject of the email. * **Body** – The text of the email (you may edit the text style as you wish). * **Send Recovery Notification** – Adds the selected recipient to the recovery notification list. When the Incident is recovered, all recipients on the recovery list are notified. * **Attachments** – The path of the file/s you wish to attach to the email (e.g., `\\exchange-srv\logs\log.txt`). * Alternatively, enter the variable returned from the [LINK] activity (e.g., `%loadRemoteFile1.File%`). You can add multiple attachments to the email by pressing **Enter** and typing another attachment's path.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Module Name** – Select the module instance that will provide the email functionality. Do either of the following:
   * Select the module instance from the drop-down list.
     :::note
     Only module instances that you have [write access](../../Product-Navigation/Configuration/Integrations-and-Modules/access-control-on-integrations-and-modules.mdx) to appear in the list.
     :::
   * Enter a reference to a variable (like `%moduleName%`) that contains the module instance name.  
     In case the variable value is empty, the activity attempts to use the default module instance of that type. If the value is not an actual instance name, the activity returns an error.
     :::caution
     Passing a module instance name as a variable allows the use of any module instance even if it doesn't give write permissions to the current user.
     :::
* **"To" Destination Type** – The email's recipient/s.
* **"CC" Destination Type** – The email's CC recipient/s.  
   * **User** – A specific User in Actions Recipients Repository.  
   * **Group** – All Users in a Group.  
   * **Last Response** – The recipient who took responsibility for the Incident that triggered the Workflow.  
     :::note
     You can add multiple email addresses in the following convention: `<address1>;<address2>`.
     :::
     :::note
     You cannot create or edit users within an activity. User configuration must be managed within the users area.
     :::
* **Message Type** – The type of message sent to the recipient/s via email:  
   * **Original** – The message that triggered the Workflow.  
   *  **Custom** – Any entered free text.  
   *  **Template** – A predefined message.  
   :::note
   Message templates are created via the General page of the Repository section.
   :::
   *  **Subject** – The subject of the email.
   *  **Body** – The text of the email (you may edit the text style as you wish).
   *  **Send Recovery Notification** – Adds the selected recipient to the recovery notification list. When the Incident is recovered, all recipients on the recovery list are notified.
* **Attachments** – The path of the file/s you wish to attach to the email (e.g., `\\exchange-srv\logs\log.txt`).
   * Alternatively, enter the variable returned from the [Load Remote File](../Files-and-Folders/Files/load-remote-file.mdx) activity (e.g., `%loadRemoteFile1.File%`). You can add multiple attachments to the email by pressing **Enter** and typing another attachment's path.

chunks.content: This activity retrieves a password from a CyberArk safe. :::note To use this activity, verify that the CyberArk SDK .dll file "NetPasswordSDK.dll" exists in the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL Server installation folder. This .dll file will not be provided by Resolve. :::
chunks.originalContent:
This activity retrieves a password from a CyberArk safe.

:::note
To use this activity, verify that the CyberArk SDK .dll file "NetPasswordSDK.dll" exists in the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL Server installation folder. This .dll file will not be provided by Resolve.
:::

chunks.content: * **Safe** – The name of the CyberArk safe. Example: `AcmeSafe` * **Folder:** The name of the folder in which the safe is located. Example: `root` * **Application:** The name of the application for which to retrieve a password. Example: `Resolve Actions` * **Object:** The name of the object for which to retrieve a password. Example: `OperatingSystem-WinDomain-127.0.0.1` * **Port:** The port through which to connect to the CyberArk safe (the default port is 18923). * **Reason**: A free text field used for adding comments. Example: `Retrieve a password - Resolve Actions`
chunks.originalContent:
* **Safe** – The name of the CyberArk safe.  
   Example: `AcmeSafe`
* **Folder:** The name of the folder in which the safe is located.  
   Example: `root`
* **Application:** The name of the application for which to retrieve a password.  
   Example: `Resolve Actions`
* **Object:** The name of the object for which to retrieve a password.  
   Example: `OperatingSystem-WinDomain-127.0.0.1`
* **Port:** The port through which to connect to the CyberArk safe (the default port is 18923).
* **Reason**: A free text field used for adding comments.  
   Example: `Retrieve a password - Resolve Actions`

chunks.content: Data mapping allows you to parse and map JSON-formatted data to multiple variables based on a provided schema.
chunks.originalContent: Data mapping allows you to parse and map JSON-formatted data to multiple variables based on a provided schema.

chunks.content: To generate the Data Map activity: 1. Navigate to the hamburger icon on the top left and click **Builder > Workflow Designer.** 2. Create a new **Activity** -- _Data Mapping._ # Settings * **Data Source** - The source of the incoming data. The data source is a variable or the result of another Activity (e.g., an HTTP Request). * **Data Type** - The type of data mapped. Select JSON or XML. * **Schema** - Defines the structure and format expected for the JSON data. This Activity will use the schema to validate the JSON, checking for errors such as misspellings or issues from copy/pasting. _The 'Generate Map' button will be enabled when the JSON conforms to the schema._ * **Generate Map** - The button to activate data mapping. The button is only available when a valid schema is specified. Clicking this button will map all available paths to variables used in the Workflow. * **Variable Map** - A table showing the mappings for variables. * The _Name_ column represents the variables that will be named for reference in the Workflow. * The _Value_ column represents the path the Data Mapping Activity uses to parse the result from the incoming data. For JSON, these are JSON Paths. # Output The output of the Data Mapping Activity is multiple variables based on properties within the parsed JSON response. The output is similar to the JSON to Table Activity.
chunks.originalContent:
To generate the Data Map activity:
1. Navigate to the hamburger icon on the top left and click **Builder > Workflow Designer.**
2. Create a new **Activity** -- _Data Mapping._

# Settings

* **Data Source** - The source of the incoming data. The data source is a variable or the result of another Activity (e.g., an HTTP Request).

* **Data Type** - The type of data mapped. Select JSON or XML.

* **Schema** - Defines the structure and format expected for the JSON data. This Activity will use the schema to validate the JSON, checking for errors such as misspellings or issues from copy/pasting. _The 'Generate Map' button will be enabled when the JSON conforms to the schema._

* **Generate Map** - The button to activate data mapping. The button is only available when a valid schema is specified. Clicking this button will map all available paths to variables used in the Workflow.

* **Variable Map** - A table showing the mappings for variables. 
    * The _Name_ column represents the variables that will be named for reference in the Workflow. 
    * The _Value_ column represents the path the Data Mapping Activity uses to parse the result from the incoming data. For JSON, these are JSON Paths.

# Output

The output of the Data Mapping Activity is multiple variables based on properties within the parsed JSON response. The output is similar to the JSON to Table Activity.

chunks.content: A schema must be provided to use the _Generate Map_ button. Clicking _Generate Map_ will automatically populate the mapping table using the property names as variable names. The provided JSON keys will set their values. :::note The variable names can be changed if desired. :::
chunks.originalContent:
A schema must be provided to use the _Generate Map_ button.

Clicking _Generate Map_ will automatically populate the mapping table using the property names as variable names. The provided JSON keys will set their values.

:::note
The variable names can be changed if desired.
:::

chunks.content: # Example Given the JSON schema: [CODE_BLOCK] The _Generate Map_ activity will produce: | Name | Value | |------|------| |name| name| |rotation_period|rotation_period| |orbital_period|orbital_period| |diameter|diameter| |climate|climate| |gravity|gravity| |terrain|terrain| |surface_water|surface_water| |population|population| |films.[0]|films.[0]| |created|created| |edited|edited| |url|url| :::note Variables can be renamed or manually added. :::
chunks.originalContent:
# Example

Given the JSON schema: 

```
{
    "name": "Yavin IV", 
    "rotation_period": "24", 
    "orbital_period": "4818", 
    "diameter": "10200", 
    "climate": "temperate, tropical", 
    "gravity": "1 standard", 
    "terrain": "jungle, rainforests", 
    "surface_water": "8", 
    "population": "1000", 
    "residents": [], 
    "films": [
        "https://swapi.dev/api/films/1/"
    ], 
    "created": "2014-12-10T11:37:19.144000Z", 
    "edited": "2014-12-20T20:58:18.421000Z", 
    "url": "https://swapi.dev/api/planets/3/"
}
```

The _Generate Map_ activity will produce: 

| Name | Value |
|------|------|
|name| name|
|rotation_period|rotation_period|
|orbital_period|orbital_period|
|diameter|diameter|
|climate|climate|
|gravity|gravity|
|terrain|terrain|
|surface_water|surface_water|
|population|population|
|films.[0]|films.[0]|
|created|created|
|edited|edited|
|url|url|

:::note

Variables can be renamed or manually added.

:::

chunks.content: Once mapped, the variables can be used in other activities.
chunks.originalContent: Once mapped, the variables can be used in other activities.

chunks.content: [CODE_BLOCK]
chunks.originalContent:
```
The gravity on planet %name% is %gravity%.
```

Database activities are used to query (retrieve data) from different database types or update (insert data) them.

:::note
For additional information on all connection-string related issues, visit [www.connectionstrings.com](https://www.connectionstrings.com).
:::

Example: `%NewTable%` * **Table Name** – The name of the new table. * **Schema Name** – Schema name, if required. * **Table Space** – Table space, if required.

chunks.content: A ResultSet. :::note To use DB2 activities, you need to download the latest version of the Data Server Driver Package from the [LINK] and install it on the machine where the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL executor is installed. After installing the Data Server Driver Package, contact your Resolve representative for updating the path to the package in the activity's configuration. :::
chunks.originalContent:
A ResultSet.

:::note
To use DB2 activities, you need to download the latest version of the Data Server Driver Package from the [IBM website](http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=4020&uid=swg27016878) and install it on the machine where the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL executor is installed.  
After installing the Data Server Driver Package, contact your Resolve representative for updating the path to the package in the activity's configuration.
:::

chunks.content: * **Query** – The query's text. For example, `Select * from administrator.catalog`. * **Connection String** – Specifies the required connection string in order to connect the database. Example: `Server=192.168.1.10:50000;Database=SAMPLE;` * **User Authentication** – Determines whether a user's authentication credentials are required to execute the query (if the credentials are not specified in the clear text connection string). * **User name** – A DB2 user authorized to execute the query (e.g., `sa`). * **Password** – The user's password. :::note To avoid translation of `%TEXT.%` (in case `TEXT` is not a variable name), add `@` before the percentage character. For example: `Select * From TableName Where ColumnName LIKE '@%TEXT%'` ::: :::note To use the word `variable` within a query, use the following convention: `@%variable%` (else it is referred to as a system variable). :::
chunks.originalContent:
* **Query** – The query's text. For example, `Select * from administrator.catalog`.
* **Connection String** – Specifies the required connection string in order to connect the database.  
  Example: `Server=192.168.1.10:50000;Database=SAMPLE;`
* **User Authentication** – Determines whether a user's authentication credentials are required to execute the query (if the credentials are not specified in the clear text connection string).
* **User name** – A DB2 user authorized to execute the query (e.g., `sa`).
* **Password** – The user's password.

:::note
To avoid translation of `%TEXT.%` (in case `TEXT` is not a variable name), add `@` before the percentage character. For example: `Select * From TableName Where ColumnName LIKE '@%TEXT%'`

:::note
To use the word `variable` within a query, use the following convention: `@%variable%` (else it is referred to as a system variable).
:::

For example, Delete from logs. * **Connection String** – Specifies the required connection string in order to connect the database. Example: `Server=SRV01;Database=myDataBase;` * **User Authentication** – Determines whether a user's authentication credentials are required to execute the query (if the credentials are not specified in the clear text connection string). * **User Name** – A MySQL user authorized to execute the query (e.g., `sa`). * **Password** – The user's password. :::note To avoid translation of `%TEXT%` (in case `TEXT` is not a variable name), add `@` before the percentage character. For example: `Select * From TableName Where ColumnName LIKE '@%TEXT%'`. ::: :::note To use the word `variable` within a statement, use the following convention: `@%variable%` (else it is referred to as a system variable). :::
chunks.originalContent:
* **Statement** – The query's text (e.g., `Delete from hosts Where name='server1'`). For example, Delete from logs.
* **Connection String** – Specifies the required connection string in order to connect the database.  
  Example: `Server=SRV01;Database=myDataBase;`
* **User Authentication** – Determines whether a user's authentication credentials are required to execute the query (if the credentials are not specified in the clear text connection string).
* **User Name** – A MySQL user authorized to execute the query (e.g., `sa`).
* **Password** – The user's password.

:::note
To avoid translation of `%TEXT%` (in case `TEXT` is not a variable name), add `@` before the percentage character. For example: `Select * From TableName Where ColumnName LIKE '@%TEXT%'`.
:::

:::note
To use the word `variable` within a statement, use the following convention: `@%variable%` (else it is referred to as a system variable).
:::

chunks.content: Executes a PowerShell script on a local device. Windows PowerShell is Microsoft's task automation framework, consisting of a command-line shell and associated scripting language built on top of and integrated with the .NET Framework. PowerShell provides full access to COM and WMI, enabling administrators to perform administrative tasks on both local and remote Windows systems. :::note The PowerShell package must be installed on the server on which the script is executed. ::: :::note The activity does not support a 32-bit MS Windows installation. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Executes a PowerShell script on a local device. Windows PowerShell is Microsoft's task automation framework, consisting of a command-line shell and associated scripting language built on top of and integrated with the .NET Framework. PowerShell provides full access to COM and WMI, enabling administrators to perform administrative tasks on both local and remote Windows systems.

:::note
The PowerShell package must be installed on the server on which the script is executed.
:::

:::note
The activity does not support a 32-bit MS Windows installation.
:::

chunks.content: FTP activities allow you to manage FTP Server contents: create folders and files, delete them, upload contents to the FTP server and download contents from it. In a typical FTP workflow, you start an FTP session, get the desired information or upload any file to the FTP server, and then terminate the FTP session. Each FTP activity between the Start FTP Session activity and Terminate FTP Session activity should refer to the started session's name. The following image depicts a typical FTP workflow: [IMAGE]
chunks.originalContent:
FTP activities allow you to manage FTP Server contents: create folders and files, delete them, upload contents to the FTP server and download contents from it.

In a typical FTP workflow, you start an FTP session, get the desired information or upload any file to the FTP server, and then terminate the FTP session. Each FTP activity between the Start FTP Session activity and Terminate FTP Session activity should refer to the started session's name.

The following image depicts a typical FTP workflow:

![FTP_Workflow.png](img/163a30d86343c9.png)

   Example: `/upload`

chunks.content: Lists the files attached to the email that triggered the workflow (saved to `C:\Program Files\Resolve\Actions Express Server\Files`). Wildcards are supported (e.g., file type).
chunks.originalContent: Lists the files attached to the email that triggered the workflow (saved to `C:\Program Files\Resolve\Actions Express Server\Files`). Wildcards are supported (e.g., file type).

chunks.content: * **Name Pattern** – The attachment file criteria. This field can be left empty. For example, to retrieve all XML files attached to the triggering email, enter `*.xml`). :::note To control the download attachment parameters you can: * Access Actions `C:\Program Files\Resolve\Actions Express Email Server\Email Server.exe.config` and edit the file using a text editor. * Change the following key parameters: * **DownloadAttachments** – Used to determine whether to download the files attached to emails arriving at Actions (can be set to either True or False). * **IgnoreAttachmentsFiles** – Used to ignore specific file types (any type of file extension can be set, e.g., `<addkey="IgnoreAttachmentsFiles" value="*.gif;*.jpeg"/>`. The parameter should be copied and edited per ignored file type). :::
chunks.originalContent:
* **Name Pattern** – The attachment file criteria. This field can be left empty.

For example, to retrieve all XML files attached to the triggering email, enter `*.xml`).

:::note
To control the download attachment parameters you can:

* Access Actions `C:\Program Files\Resolve\Actions Express Email Server\Email Server.exe.config` and edit the file using a text editor.
* Change the following key parameters:
    * **DownloadAttachments** – Used to determine whether to download the files attached to emails arriving at Actions (can be set to either True or False).
    * **IgnoreAttachmentsFiles** – Used to ignore specific file types (any type of file extension can be set, e.g., `<addkey="IgnoreAttachmentsFiles" value="*.gif;*.jpeg"/>`. The parameter should be copied and edited per ignored file type).
:::

chunks.content: Files and Folders activities are used to create, change, delete or extract data from files and folders. :::note When accessing a local machine (or the machine that triggered the workflow), use regular path convention (e.g., `c:\...`). When accessing a remote machine or a shared location use the UNC `\\<Shared Folder Name>`. ::: :::note You can use wildcards to indicate unpredictable factors in the file names, e.g., `*.xml` :::
chunks.originalContent:
Files and Folders activities are used to create, change, delete or extract data from files and folders.

:::note
When accessing a local machine (or the machine that triggered the workflow), use regular path convention (e.g., `c:\...`). When accessing a remote machine or a shared location use the UNC `\\<Shared Folder Name>`.
:::

:::note
You can use wildcards to indicate unpredictable factors in the file names, e.g., `*.xml`
:::

chunks.content: * **Recursive** – Determines whether the search is recursive or not**.** * **Path** – The path of the folder (e.g., `c:\logs\*.txt`). * **Host Name** – The host name or IP address. * **User Name** – If required, the username of an account that has read-write access to the host. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field. * **Time Filter** – Determines whether to use a time filter. * **Filter** – The type of time filter (creation time, accessed time or modification time). * **Condition** – The type of time conditioning (**older than** or **during last**). * **days, hrs, mins, secs** – Sets the time frame according to which the time filter operates.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Recursive** – Determines whether the search is recursive or not**.**
* **Path** – The path of the folder (e.g., `c:\logs\*.txt`).
* **Host Name** – The host name or IP address.
* **User Name** – If required, the username of an account that has read-write access to the host.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
* **Time Filter** – Determines whether to use a time filter.
    * **Filter** – The type of time filter (creation time, accessed time or modification time).

chunks.originalContent:
A ResultSet of the file's content.

:::note
This activity supports Excel 2003, Excel 2007, Excel 2010 and Excel 2014 files.
:::

In case of a duplicated column name, one column will be renamed.
:::

chunks.content: * **Path** – The path where the file is stored. * **Host Name** – The host name or IP address. * **User Name** – If required, the username of an account that has read-write access to the host. * **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field. * **Sheet Name** – The name of the sheet to read. If blank, the first sheet will be read. * **Range** – The range of cells to read. If blank, all cells in the specified sheet will be read. Example: `a1:b45` * **My table has header** – checkbox to mark if the sheet has a header row. If unchecked, the first row of cells will be counted as part of the data and not a header row.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Path** – The path where the file is stored.
* **Host Name** – The host name or IP address.
* **User Name** – If required, the username of an account that has read-write access to the host.
* **Password** – If required, the password of the account listed in the User Name field.
* **Sheet Name** – The name of the sheet to read. If blank, the first sheet will be read.
* **Range** – The range of cells to read. If blank, all cells in the specified sheet will be read.  
   Example: `a1:b45`
* **My table has header** – checkbox to mark if the sheet has a header row. If unchecked, the first row of cells will be counted as part of the data and not a header row.

:::note
Some activities support setting only the HyperV server or only the SCVMM server, according to the specific action.

Set the SCVMM checkbox to force the activity to approach the SCVMM server only.

chunks.content: A ResultSet of all matching events/flows.
chunks.originalContent: A ResultSet of all matching events/flows.

chunks.content: * **Module Name** – The name of the IBM QRadar module that will execute this activity. * **Event Type** – The type of event you wish to get details for. Events are correlated to Log Activity, and Flows are correlated to Network Activity. * **Time Frame** – When selecting a time frame (either predefined or custom), only days/hours/minutes are respected. Seconds are rounded off to the nearest minute. This affects the results returned for the specific time frame. * **From Time** – Choose the From Time (custom) for the event. * **To Time** – Choose the To Time (custom) for the event. * **Filters** – Filters are applied (by the activity) to events/flows that contain values in the specified field. Filters should be as specific as possible.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Module Name** – The name of the IBM QRadar module that will execute this activity.
* **Event Type** – The type of event you wish to get details for. Events are correlated to Log Activity, and Flows are correlated to Network Activity.
* **Time Frame** – When selecting a time frame (either predefined or custom), only days/hours/minutes are respected. Seconds are rounded off to the nearest minute. This affects the results returned for the specific time frame.
* **From Time** – Choose the From Time (custom) for the event.
* **To Time** – Choose the To Time (custom) for the event.
* **Filters** – Filters are applied (by the activity) to events/flows that contain values in the specified field. Filters should be as specific as possible.

chunks.content: Changes the severity level of an incident.
chunks.originalContent: Changes the severity level of an incident.

chunks.content: * **Use Current Incident/Use Another Incident** – Determines whether to change the severity of the incident that triggered the workflow, or another incident. * **Type: Device/Service** – Determines whether the incident is ascribed to a Device or a Service. * **Name** – The name of the constant/dynamic incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection). * **Classification** – The classification of the incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection). * **Automatically Change the Severity** – Increases or decreases the incident's severity level by 1, regardless of its current level. * **Or, manually select the Severity** – Sets the incident's severity level to one of the following constant values: Info, Warning, Minor, Major, Critical or a Variable's value (e.g., %Severity%).
chunks.originalContent:
* **Use Current Incident/Use Another Incident** – Determines whether to change the severity of the incident that triggered the workflow, or another incident.
* **Type: Device/Service** – Determines whether the incident is ascribed to a Device or a Service.
* **Name** – The name of the constant/dynamic incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection).
* **Classification** – The classification of the incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection).
* **Automatically Change the Severity** – Increases or decreases the incident's severity level by 1, regardless of its current level.
* **Or, manually select the Severity** – Sets the incident's severity level to one of the following constant values: Info, Warning, Minor, Major, Critical or a Variable's value (e.g., %Severity%).

Example: `%DeviceName%` * **Classification** – The classification of the incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection). Example: `%AlertType%`
chunks.originalContent:
* **Type: Device/Service** – Determines whether the incident is ascribed to a Device or a Service.
* **Name** – The name of the constant/dynamic incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection).  
   Example: `%DeviceName%`
* **Classification** – The classification of the incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection).

chunks.content: Closes an incident (the activity does not terminate the workflow).
chunks.originalContent: Closes an incident (the activity does not terminate the workflow).

chunks.content: * **Use Current Incident/Use Another Incident** – Determines whether to close the incident that triggered the workflow, or another incident. * **Type: Device/Service** – Determines whether the incident is ascribed to a Device or a Service. * **Name** – The name of the constant/dynamic incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection). Example: `%DeviceName%` * **Classification** – The classification of the incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection). Example: `%AlertType%` * **Reason** – The reason for closing the incident is registered to the workflow's log. The reason is documented in Actions Incident History. * **Send Notification** – Notify the recipients who received the previous notification within the scope of this incident. All recipients will be contacted via the same manner they were previously contacted. * **Terminate Workflow** – Check to terminate the workflow that was triggered by the incident.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Use Current Incident/Use Another Incident** – Determines whether to close the incident that triggered the workflow, or another incident.
* **Type: Device/Service** – Determines whether the incident is ascribed to a Device or a Service.
* **Name** – The name of the constant/dynamic incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection).  
   Example: `%DeviceName%`
* **Classification** – The classification of the incident's Device/Service (if you selected using a constant incident, the list changes according to Type selection).  
   Example: `%AlertType%`
* **Reason** – The reason for closing the incident is registered to the workflow's log. The reason is documented in Actions Incident History.
* **Send Notification** – Notify the recipients who received the previous notification within the scope of this incident. All recipients will be contacted via the same manner they were previously contacted.
* **Terminate Workflow** – Check to terminate the workflow that was triggered by the incident.

chunks.content: * **Source** – The source from which the new event originates. Example: `%source@example.com%` * **Destination** – The address to which the new event's alert is sent. This can be any value; the event will be sent to Actions either way. Example: `%dest@example.com%` * **Subject** – The subject of the event's alert. * **Body** – The body text of the event's alert.

chunks.originalContent:
* **Type: Device/Service** – Determines whether the incident is ascribed to a Device or a Service.

chunks.content: Incidents activities are used to manage VAR::PRODUCT_FULL incidents. Incident definition and configuration is performed via Actions Incident Configuration. :::note Incident activities support constant/changing device, service and classification; i.e., an incident can be ascribed to a permanent device/service and classification, or to variables representing the device/service and classification. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Incidents activities are used to manage VAR::PRODUCT_FULL incidents. Incident definition and configuration is performed via Actions Incident Configuration.

:::note
Incident activities support constant/changing device, service and classification; i.e., an incident can be ascribed to a permanent device/service and classification, or to variables representing the device/service and classification.
:::

chunks.content: The incident report.
chunks.originalContent: The incident report.

chunks.content: * **Incidents** – Use the default selected incidents, or use a variable that contains the incidents that will appear in the report. * **Devices** – Use the default selected devices, or use a variable that contains the devices that will appear in the report. * **Services** – Use the default selected services, or use a variable that contains the services that will appear in the report. * **Classification** – Use the default selected classifications, or use a variable that contains the classifications that will appear in the report. * **States** – Use the default selected states, or use a variable that contains the states that will appear in the report. * **Event (Contains)** – Events containing the specified string will appear in the report. * **Severities** – Use the default selected severities, or use a variable that contains the severities that will appear in the report. * **Time Zone** – Use the default selected time zones, or use a variable that contains the time zones that will appear in the report. * **Start Date/Current Date** – Uses the current date as the start date. * **Start Date/Default Values** – Uses the default values as the start date. * **Start Date/# Days Back** – Uses the given # of days back as the start date. * **Start Date/Variable** – Uses a variable as the start date. * **Start Date/Format** – Uses the selected format as the start date. * **End Date/Current Date** – Uses the current date as the end date. * **End Date/Default Values** – Uses the default values as the end date. * **End Date/# Days Back** – Uses the given # of days back as the end date. * **End Date/Variable** – Uses a variable as the end date. * **Output/Save Type** – Saves the executed report to file, active logs, or active logs & file. * **Output/Format** – The format of the executed report. * **Output/Path** – The path of the file in which to save the report. Example: `C:\Reports\Incidents` * **Output/Host Name** – The name of the host in which to save the report.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Incidents** – Use the default selected incidents, or use a variable that contains the incidents that will appear in the report.
* **Devices** – Use the default selected devices, or use a variable that contains the devices that will appear in the report.
* **Services** – Use the default selected services, or use a variable that contains the services that will appear in the report.
* **Classification** – Use the default selected classifications, or use a variable that contains the classifications that will appear in the report.
* **States** – Use the default selected states, or use a variable that contains the states that will appear in the report.
* **Event (Contains)** – Events containing the specified string will appear in the report.
* **Severities** – Use the default selected severities, or use a variable that contains the severities that will appear in the report.
* **Time Zone** – Use the default selected time zones, or use a variable that contains the time zones that will appear in the report.
* **Start Date/Current Date** – Uses the current date as the start date.
* **Start Date/Default Values** – Uses the default values as the start date.
* **Start Date/# Days Back** – Uses the given # of days back as the start date.
* **Start Date/Variable** – Uses a variable as the start date.
* **Start Date/Format** – Uses the selected format as the start date.
* **End Date/Current Date** – Uses the current date as the end date.
* **End Date/Default Values** – Uses the default values as the end date.
* **End Date/# Days Back** – Uses the given # of days back as the end date.
* **End Date/Variable** – Uses a variable as the end date.
* **Output/Save Type** – Saves the executed report to file, active logs, or active logs & file.
* **Output/Format** – The format of the executed report.
* **Output/Path** – The path of the file in which to save the report.  
    Example: `C:\Reports\Incidents`
* **Output/Host Name** – The name of the host in which to save the report.

chunks.content: Returns the paths of all instances of a key found in the JSON session.
chunks.originalContent: Returns the paths of all instances of a key found in the JSON session.

chunks.content: The output contains a memory table with a pair of columns: the key path and the key's parent's path. Each instance of the key that was found is a separate row. :::note You can use the [LINK], [LINK], [LINK], and [LINK] activities to manipulate the result. :::
chunks.originalContent:
The output contains a memory table with a pair of columns: the key path and the key's parent's path. Each instance of the key that was found is a separate row.

:::note
You can use the [Table](../../Activity-Repository/Tables/Table/Introduction-to-Table.mdx), [Row](../../Activity-Repository/Tables/Row/Introduction-to-Row.mdx), [Column](../../Activity-Repository/Tables/Column/introduction-to-column), and [Cell](../../Activity-Repository/Tables/Cell/Introduction-to-Cell.mdx) activities to manipulate the result.
:::

chunks.content: Jira activities are used to manage Jira tickets and can be customized according to your Jira project's requirements. :::note After dragging each activity and dropping it in the Sequential Workflow pane, you will be asked to define two parameters: issue type and project name. Once you have selected the issue and project, filled in the information in the next window and clicked OK, you will not be able to change these parameters. ::: :::note The activities are displayed as they appear by default, without any user customization. ::: :::note The integration module user must have Jira Administrator permissions to configure and manage Jira projects in Actions. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Jira activities are used to manage Jira tickets and can be customized according to your Jira project's requirements.

:::note
After dragging each activity and dropping it in the Sequential Workflow pane, you will be asked to define two parameters: issue type and project name. Once you have selected the issue and project, filled in the information in the next window and clicked OK, you will not be able to change these parameters.
:::

:::note
The activities are displayed as they appear by default, without any user customization.
:::

:::note
The integration module user must have Jira Administrator permissions to configure and manage Jira projects in Actions.
:::

chunks.content: * **Module Name** – The Jira module. * **Project Name** – The Jira project in which to update the new issue. * **Issue Type** – The type of the issue to update. * **Issue Key** – The key of the issue to update. * **Properties** – The properties of the selected issue type. :::note If there are no existing issues in Jira for the selected Issue Type, the module will not be able to discover the issue's properties. To resolve this problem, manually create an issue for the selected issue type and clear the module's cache. ::: :::note To set the value of Label, Multiple Choice, Radio Button and Checkbox type properties, select the required action from the Update Issue activity and change one value at a time. ::: :::note To set the value of Select List Cascading type fields, use the following format: Value1: Value1.1 (Value 1 is the value to the parent list and Value1.1 is the value to the child list). ::: :::note Not all special characters are supported when used in Jira properties names. Using unsupported special characters may case failure to communicate with the Jira module. :::
chunks.originalContent:
* **Module Name** – The Jira module.
* **Project Name** – The Jira project in which to update the new issue.
* **Issue Type** – The type of the issue to update.
* **Issue Key** – The key of the issue to update.
* **Properties** – The properties of the selected issue type.

:::note
If there are no existing issues in Jira for the selected Issue Type, the module will not be able to discover the issue's properties. To resolve this problem, manually create an issue for the selected issue type and clear the module's cache.
:::

:::note
To set the value of Label, Multiple Choice, Radio Button and Checkbox type properties, select the required action from the Update Issue activity and change one value at a time.
:::

:::note
To set the value of Select List Cascading type fields, use the following format: Value1: Value1.1 (Value 1 is the value to the parent list and Value1.1 is the value to the child list).
:::

:::note
Not all special characters are supported when used in Jira properties names. Using unsupported special characters may case failure to communicate with the Jira module.
:::

chunks.content: McAfee ESM activities are used in the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL McAfee ESM integration module that provides a bidirectional communication channel between McAfee ESM and VAR::PRODUCT. After you add and configure the module, AR::PRODUCT pulls new created alerts and updates, translates them into incidents, and displays them in the Actions dashboard. :::note To use these activities, you need to have a configured and enabled McAfee ESM integration module. :::
chunks.originalContent:
McAfee ESM activities are used in the VAR::PRODUCT_FULL McAfee ESM integration module that provides a bidirectional communication channel between McAfee ESM and VAR::PRODUCT. After you add and configure the module, AR::PRODUCT pulls new created alerts and updates, translates them into incidents, and displays them in the Actions dashboard.

:::note
To use these activities, you need to have a configured and enabled McAfee ESM integration module.
:::
