chunks.content: To add a trigger: 1. From the top right corner of the trigger list, click the plus icon. The trigger properties screen appears. 2. In the **Name** field, enter the name of the trigger. For example: "Web Portal Recovery". 3. In the **Description** field, enter a description for the trigger. 4. Clear **Enable** to currently disable the trigger. 5. Clear **Audit Log** do avoid the triggered workflow to register to the [LINK]. 6. Check **Terminating Action** if you wish to terminate the trigger list check when the current trigger is activated. 7. Next to **Timing Constraints**, select the [LINK], in which the trigger is active, or select **Always**. 8. Under **Conditions**: 1. Under **Condition**, select a [LINK] checked from the drop-down list or select **Any** if you wish to initiate the workflow upon any incoming event. :::note To catch any incoming events that were dropped by the listed triggers, it is recommended to use the **Any** option in the last trigger. The workflow activated by this trigger can notify the administrator of any unhandled event. ::: 2. Under **Workflow**, select the [LINK] that will be activated when the condition applies. 3. Under **Recovery Workflow**, select the workflow to run after recovery from the incident. 4. Under **Time Frame**, select the time frame in which the condition applies. 5. Under **Log Folder** select the [LINK] to which this workflow run will be registered. 6. Repeat the steps for each additional workflow you wish to add to the trigger. 9. Click **Save**.
chunks.originalContent:
To add a trigger:

1. From the top right corner of the trigger list, click the plus icon.  
   The trigger properties screen appears.
2. In the **Name** field, enter the name of the trigger.  
   For example: "Web Portal Recovery".
3. In the **Description** field, enter a description for the trigger.
4. Clear **Enable** to currently disable the trigger.
5. Clear **Audit Log** do avoid the triggered workflow to register to the [Audit Trail](../../Insight/Audit-Trail/viewing-the-audit-trail-log.mdx).
6. Check **Terminating Action** if you wish to terminate the trigger list check when the current trigger is activated.
7. Next to **Timing Constraints**, select the [Time Frame](../General/Time-Frames.mdx), in which the trigger is active, or select **Always**.
8. Under **Conditions**:
   1. Under **Condition**, select a [condition](../General/Conditions.mdx) checked from the drop-down list or select **Any** if you wish to initiate the workflow upon any incoming event.  
      :::note
      To catch any incoming events that were dropped by the listed triggers, it is recommended to use the **Any** option in the last trigger. The workflow activated by this trigger can notify the administrator of any unhandled event.
      :::
   2. Under **Workflow**, select the [workflow](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/introduction.mdx) that will be activated when the condition applies.
   3. Under **Recovery Workflow**, select the workflow to run after recovery from the incident.
   4. Under **Time Frame**, select the time frame in which the condition applies.
   5. Under **Log Folder** select the [log folder](../../Insight/Audit-Trail/viewing-the-audit-trail-log.mdx#displaying-the-event-log) to which this workflow run will be registered.
   6. Repeat the steps for each additional workflow you wish to add to the trigger.
9. Click **Save**.

chunks.content: [IMAGE] Schedules and Triggers are used to initiate workflows in two ways: conditional triggers and scheduled actions. When an event is retrieved by VAR::PRODUCT_FULL, the list of triggers is scanned. If the event matches the criteria of a specific trigger, the workflow assigned to it is initiated. In addition, workflows may be initiated periodically, according to specific time slot. For example: the workflow "Clean log file folder" can be set to run every Sunday at 2:00 AM. :::note For more information on workflows refer to [LINK] ::: Choosing **Repository > Schedules and Triggers** from the Navigation menu opens the following window: [IMAGE]
chunks.originalContent:
![](img/1638e0057c8a11.png)

Schedules and Triggers are used to initiate workflows in two ways: conditional triggers and scheduled actions. 

When an event is retrieved by VAR::PRODUCT_FULL, the list of triggers is scanned. If the event matches the criteria of a specific trigger, the workflow assigned to it is initiated.

In addition, workflows may be initiated periodically, according to specific time slot. For example: the workflow "Clean log file folder" can be set to run every Sunday at 2:00 AM.

:::note
For more information on workflows refer to [Welcome to the Workflow Designers](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/introduction.mdx)
:::

Choosing **Repository > Schedules and Triggers** from the Navigation menu opens the following window:

![](img/Actions_Repository_TriggersandSchedules.png)

chunks.content: The **Workflows** section under **Repositories** provides facilities to manage both your workflows and your templates. If you only use prepared workflows, then this section will provide a catalog of available workflows. You will probably not need the Templates section. If however, you prepare or modify workflows, this section will show you how to catalog your workflows into folders. It will also show you how to catalog your templates.
chunks.originalContent: The **Workflows** section under **Repositories** provides facilities to manage both your workflows and your templates. If you only use prepared workflows, then this section will provide a catalog of available workflows. You will probably not need the Templates section. If however, you prepare or modify workflows, this section will show you how to catalog your workflows into folders. It will also show you how to catalog your templates.

chunks.content: :::note The treatment here is very brief. Manipulating templates require familiarity with the [LINK] where their management is covered in detail. ::: From the Main Menu, open the **Templates** entity. You will see a list like this: [IMAGE] * For a new system you are presented with a catalog of pre-installed folders and templates. Notice that the last item, **Security**, contains subfolders. * The icons and drop-down action lists are functionally the same as those for workflows. * Moving and copying templates follows the same patters as workflows. Copying to a new folder by export import works as expected. You will also need to validate an imported template through the Workflow Designer. * In an existing system, your own templates will appear in the catalog under your own folders. * The icons and drop-down action lists are functionally the same as those for workflows. * Moving and copying templates follows the same patters as workflows. Copying to a new folder by export import works as expected. You will also need to validate an imported template through the Workflow Designer.
chunks.originalContent:
:::note
The treatment here is very brief. Manipulating templates require familiarity with the [Workflow Designer](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/introduction.mdx) where their management is covered in detail.
:::

From the Main Menu, open the **Templates** entity. You will see a list like this:

![Templates_Main.png](img/Actions_Workflows_Templates.png)

*   For a new system you are presented with a catalog of pre-installed folders and templates. Notice that the last item, **Security**, contains subfolders.
*   The icons and drop-down action lists are functionally the same as those for workflows.
*   Moving and copying templates follows the same patters as workflows. Copying to a new folder by export import works as expected. You will also need to validate an imported template through the Workflow Designer.
*   In an existing system, your own templates will appear in the catalog under your own folders.
*   The icons and drop-down action lists are functionally the same as those for workflows.
*   Moving and copying templates follows the same patters as workflows. Copying to a new folder by export import works as expected. You will also need to validate an imported template through the Workflow Designer.

chunks.content: Navigate to **Repository > Workflows**. You will be offered the following display: [IMAGE] Expand the **Workflows** section. In a new system, the list contains pre-installed workflows. An existing system will also include any that you have added. If you create workflows, consider adding your own folder structure under the default **Workflows**. To create a new folder under the currently selected one, click the New Folder icon. It creates a new folder below the last in the list and invites you to enter a name:
chunks.originalContent:
Navigate to **Repository > Workflows**. You will be offered the following display:

![](img/Actions_Repository_Workflows.png)

Expand the **Workflows** section. In a new system, the list contains pre-installed workflows. An existing system will also include any that you have added. If you create workflows, consider adding your own folder structure under the default **Workflows**. To create a new folder under the currently selected one, click the New Folder icon. It creates a new folder below the last in the list and invites you to enter a name:

chunks.content: :::note The treatment here is brief since it requires familiarity with the [LINK] where it is covered in detail. ::: So far, the workflow catalog behavior is similar to a familiar computer file system. You cannot however, drag and drop workflows between folders. There are two ways to move or copy a workflow to another folder: To move a workflow to a different folder: 1. Load it into the Workflow Designer. 2. Use the **Save As** option to save the workflow into the required folder. See [LINK] for details. The workflow is moved to the required folder. To copy a workflow to a different folder: 1. Export the workflow. It will be downloaded by your browser as an XML file. 2. Import it back to the required folder. It will show with the validation icon grayed out: [IMAGE] 3. From the action list in ([LINK]), open the workflow in the Workflow Designer and click **Save**. The Save action will also validate the workflow and enable the validated indicator icon.
chunks.originalContent:
:::note
The treatment here is brief since it requires familiarity with the [Workflow Designer](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/introduction.mdx) where it is covered in detail.
:::

So far, the workflow catalog behavior is similar to a familiar computer file system. You cannot however, drag and drop workflows between folders. There are two ways to move or copy a workflow to another folder:

To move a workflow to a different folder:

1. Load it into the Workflow Designer.
2. Use the **Save As** option to save the workflow into the required folder.  
   See [Saving your workflow](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/reviewing-and-sharing.mdx) for details.  
   The workflow is moved to the required folder.

To copy a workflow to a different folder:

1. Export the workflow. It will be downloaded by your browser as an XML file.
2. Import it back to the required folder. It will show with the validation icon grayed out:  
   ![Imported Workflows](img/Actions_Repository_WorkflowsandTemplates_Workflows.png)
3. From the action list in ([Operations on Workflows](#operations-on-workflows)), open the workflow in the Workflow Designer and click **Save**.
   The Save action will also validate the workflow and enable the validated indicator icon.

chunks.content: Once variables have been set (see [LINK]), clicking on the **Run** button from **Workflows Repository** will display the **Set Values & Run** window. Users with editing permissions have the option to select which variables to be used during the workflow execution while users without editing permissions must insert values for all of the required variables to execute the workflow.
chunks.originalContent:
Once variables have been set (see [Setting Variables in Workflows](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/Variables/set-variables-in-workflows.mdx)), clicking on the **Run** button from **Workflows Repository** will display the **Set Values & Run** window.

Users with editing permissions have the option to select which variables to be used during the workflow execution while users without editing permissions must insert values for all of the required variables to execute the workflow.

chunks.content: [IMAGE] User can use the checkboxes on the left side to select which variables will be used during the workflow execution. Variables that have been set as required (marked with \*) can be unchecked if desired. Clicking on **Run** executes the workflow using the selected variables with their inserted values.
chunks.originalContent:
![](img/1638e00563f16f.png)

User can use the checkboxes on the left side to select which variables will be used during the workflow execution. Variables that have been set as required (marked with \*) can be unchecked if desired.

Clicking on **Run** executes the workflow using the selected variables with their inserted values.

chunks.content: [IMAGE] User must insert values for the variables that have been set as required (marked with \*). Variables that have not been set as required can be left empty. Clicking on **Run** executes the workflow using the variables with their inserted values.
chunks.originalContent:
![](img/1638e00564516c.png)

User must insert values for the variables that have been set as required (marked with \*). Variables that have not been set as required can be left empty.

Clicking on **Run** executes the workflow using the variables with their inserted values.

chunks.content: There are two ways to add fields to a Form: 1. **Recommended:** Choose a Workflow and generate blocks from that Workflow. 2. Manually drag and drop fields onto the Form.
chunks.originalContent:
There are two ways to add fields to a Form:

1.  **Recommended:** Choose a Workflow and generate blocks from that Workflow. 
2.  Manually drag and drop fields onto the Form.

chunks.content: Start creating a Form by adding the following metadata * Name (required) * Folder (required). Click **Add Folder** to create a folder without leaving the **Create Form** wizard. * Description * Tags :::note A description is particularly important because it will allow your users to know the purpose of the Form and when to use it. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Start creating a Form by adding the following metadata

*   Name (required)
*   Folder (required). Click **Add Folder** to create a folder without leaving the **Create Form** wizard.
*   Description
*   Tags

:::note
A description is particularly important because it will allow your users to know the purpose of the Form and when to use it.
:::

chunks.content: To automatically create blocks (fields) from a Workflow: 1. In the **Control Panel**, in **Workflow name**, select the workflow to base the form on. 2. Click **Generate Blocks**. - In the Workflow, Self Service variables appear as *Text fields* and are automatically added to the left column of the Form. The field label is the variable name. :::note You can add new fields, remove generated fields, or move fields around. Controls are generated as Text by default; to change the default, delete the current control and drag and drop a new control. :::
chunks.originalContent:
To automatically create blocks (fields) from a Workflow:

1. In the **Control Panel**, in **Workflow name**, select the workflow to base the form on.
2. Click **Generate Blocks**.  
   - In the Workflow, Self Service variables appear as *Text fields* and are automatically added to the left column of the Form. The field label is the variable name.

:::note
You can add new fields, remove generated fields, or move fields around. Controls are generated as Text by default; to change the default, delete the current control and drag and drop a new control.
:::

chunks.content: The New Form window appears the first time you enter the Self Service Designer, and when there are no forms currently open. You can also open the form creation window by clicking **Create Form** in the left navigation bar.
chunks.originalContent:
The New Form window appears the first time you enter the Self Service Designer, and when there are no forms currently open.

You can also open the form creation window by clicking **Create Form** in the left navigation bar.

chunks.content: If you don't want to use the Generate Blocks feature, you can manually drag desired fields to the Form. Manually adding fields can assist in creating a better user experience. You can add titles and organize fields into relevant groups. 1. From the **Control Panel**, click and hold the desired field type and drag it onto the Form. 2. You can also drag fields to either column in the Form.
chunks.originalContent:
If you don't want to use the Generate Blocks feature, you can manually drag desired fields to the Form. Manually adding fields can assist in creating a better user experience. You can add titles and organize fields into relevant groups. 

1. From the **Control Panel**, click and hold the desired field type and drag it onto the Form.
2. You can also drag fields to either column in the Form.
chunks.header: Manually Adding Fields to a Form
chunks.pageTitle: Manually Adding Fields to a Form

chunks.content: Follow these instructions to delete or change the name of a folder. 1. Within the Self Service Designer, hover your mouse over the folder name. 2. Click **Edit** (pencil icon) to change the folder name. :::note Folder names must be unique across all folders. ::: 3. Click **Delete** (trash can icon) to delete the folder. :::note CAUTION Deleting a folder will also delete all forms in that folder. If you do not want to delete the forms, move them before deletion. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Follow these instructions to delete or change the name of a folder.

1. Within the Self Service Designer, hover your mouse over the folder name.  
2. Click **Edit** (pencil icon) to change the folder name.  
   :::note
   Folder names must be unique across all folders.
   :::
3. Click **Delete** (trash can icon) to delete the folder.  
   :::note CAUTION
   Deleting a folder will also delete all forms in that folder. If you do not want to delete the forms, move them before deletion.
   :::

chunks.content: You must enable a Form to make it available in the [LINK]. An **enabled** form is visible in the [LINK] to all users with permission to see it. Forms that are not enabled are not visible within the Self Service Portal. Take these steps to enable a form: 1. Open the form in the Self Service Designer. 2. In the **Control Panel**, check the **Enabled** box. 3. Optionally, check **Confirm before form submission** to require users to confirm a submission when they click the Submit button in the Portal.
chunks.originalContent:
You must enable a Form to make it available in the [Self Service Portal](../Home-Page/Self-Service-Portal/introduction-to-self-service-portal.mdx).

An **enabled** form is visible in the [Self Service Portal](../Home-Page/Self-Service-Portal/introduction-to-self-service-portal.mdx) to all users with permission to see it. Forms that are not enabled are not visible within the Self Service Portal.

Take these steps to enable a form:

1. Open the form in the Self Service Designer.
2. In the **Control Panel**, check the **Enabled** box.
3. Optionally, check **Confirm before form submission** to require users to confirm a submission when they click the Submit button in the Portal.

chunks.content: To delete a field, hover over it, and click the **Trash** icon. :::note Ensure you are deleting the correct field, as there is no confirmation warning, and you cannot undo the action. :::
chunks.originalContent:
To delete a field, hover over it, and click the **Trash** icon.

:::note
Ensure you are deleting the correct field, as there is no confirmation warning, and you cannot undo the action.
:::

chunks.content: There are two ways to populate the drop-down list so that users can select the correct drop-down property value. 1. Select a workflow that will run when this Form launches. 2. Create a static list of items. :::note This is not the same Workflow used for the Form we are building, but a different one specifically for populating this field. This Workflow will return a two-column table with this table variable in a Self Service Response activity. The first column is the ID. The ID is the actual value used in the activity, and the second value is the Name, which appears on the list. ::: Take these steps to select a Workflow: 1. Click the **Name** radio button. 2. Type the name of the desired Workflow to find it in the list. 3. Select the desired Workflow. When the Form launches, the Workflow selected will run first, and the Result of that Workflow will populate the dropdown list available to the user. :::note Use this option if the list you want to generate is dynamic and subject to change. ::: Take these steps to create a static list of items: 1. Click the **List Items** radio button. 2. Type the option names that you want on the list. 3. Press **Enter** or click the enter icon to add the item to the list. 4. If you wish to delete the item, click the **Delete** icon. :::note Use the static list option when you do not expect the list to change and do not want to rely on an additional workflow to populate it. :::
chunks.originalContent:
There are two ways to populate the drop-down list so that users can select the correct drop-down property value.

1. Select a workflow that will run when this Form launches.
2. Create a static list of items.

:::note
This is not the same Workflow used for the Form we are building, but a different one specifically for populating this field. This Workflow will return a two-column table with this table variable in a Self Service Response activity.  

The first column is the ID. The ID is the actual value used in the activity, and the second value is the Name, which appears on the list.
:::

Take these steps to select a Workflow:

1. Click the **Name** radio button.
2. Type the name of the desired Workflow to find it in the list.
3. Select the desired Workflow.  
   When the Form launches, the Workflow selected will run first, and the Result of that Workflow will populate the dropdown list available to the user.

:::note
Use this option if the list you want to generate is dynamic and subject to change.
:::

Take these steps to create a static list of items:

1. Click the **List Items** radio button.
2. Type the option names that you want on the list.
3. Press **Enter** or click the enter icon to add the item to the list.
4. If you wish to delete the item, click the **Delete** icon.

:::note
Use the static list option when you do not expect the list to change and do not want to rely on an additional workflow to populate it.
:::

chunks.content: Each field has specific properties that can be modified to change how it looks and behaves. Hover over a field and click the pencil icon to display field properties. [IMAGE]
chunks.originalContent:
Each field has specific properties that can be modified to change how it looks and behaves.

Hover over a field and click the pencil icon to display field properties.

![FieldProperties.png](img/field-properties.png)

chunks.content: There are different types of fields and various ways to modify them to suit your needs.
chunks.originalContent: There are different types of fields and various ways to modify them to suit your needs.

chunks.content: A read-only field with no variable input presented to the User. Use this field to give a Title to your Form or to differentiate different sections of the Form.
chunks.originalContent:
A read-only field with no variable input presented to the User.

Use this field to give a Title to your Form or to differentiate different sections of the Form.

chunks.content: A short text field where the User can type text to populate a variable. Use this field for short variables such as: * Username * Hostname * Other short texts
chunks.originalContent:
A short text field where the User can type text to populate a variable.

Use this field for short variables such as:

* Username
* Hostname
* Other short texts

chunks.content: #### Right to Left Choose the field's text direction. If the language you are writing is right-to-left, select **Yes**. Otherwise, leave as **No**. #### Required Set a field on the form as mandatory. Any field can be designated as mandatory. A mandatory field must be completed before the user can submit the form. :::note Setting a field as mandatory does not mean there is validation on the field. ::: #### Label Change the text in the text box to update the name of the field. Format the text with bold, italics, underline, and strike-through. You can change the text color and font size, align the text, and choose from several font options. You can also leave the label field empty. Leaving the field empty will create a space in the Form rather than displaying a real label. #### Workflow Name Selecting a workflow is optional; you can either enter a label or run a Workflow when the Form is launched, and display its result (table or text) in the Form.
chunks.originalContent:
#### Right to Left

Choose the field's text direction.

If the language you are writing is right-to-left, select **Yes**. Otherwise, leave as **No**.

#### Required

Set a field on the form as mandatory.

Any field can be designated as mandatory. A mandatory field must be completed before the user can submit the form.

:::note
Setting a field as mandatory does not mean there is validation on the field. 
:::

#### Label

Change the text in the text box to update the name of the field.

Format the text with bold, italics, underline, and strike-through.

You can change the text color and font size, align the text, and choose from several font options.

You can also leave the label field empty. Leaving the field empty will create a space in the Form rather than displaying a real label.

#### Workflow Name

Selecting a workflow is optional; you can either enter a label or run a Workflow when the Form is launched, and display its result (table or text) in the Form.

chunks.content: To move a field, click and hold its four-headed arrow icon and then drag and drop it to the new location. You can move a field up or down in the field list or to the other column of the form.
chunks.originalContent:
To move a field, click and hold its four-headed arrow icon and then drag and drop it to the new location.

You can move a field up or down in the field list or to the other column of the form.

chunks.content: #### Label For Text fields, when using Generate Blocks, the label will automatically be the variable's name, which you can edit to be more friendly. #### Variable Name The variable that this field references. When the User enters a value in the portal, this field will forward the value to the Workflow. For Text fields, when using Generate Blocks, the variable name will automatically be the variable listed in the Workflow. You can choose a different variable if desired. However, you cannot use the same variable twice in the same Form. A duplicated variable will cause an error when saving.

#### Label

For Text fields, when using Generate Blocks, the label will automatically be the variable's name, which you can edit to be more friendly.

#### Variable Name

The variable that this field references.  

When the User enters a value in the portal, this field will forward the value to the Workflow.

For Text fields, when using Generate Blocks, the variable name will automatically be the variable listed in the Workflow.

You can choose a different variable if desired. However, you cannot use the same variable twice in the same Form. A duplicated variable will cause an error when saving.
chunks.header: Text, Text Area, and Password Properties
chunks.pageTitle: Text, Text Area, and Password Properties

chunks.content: It is possible to change the folder where a form resides without re-saving the Form as a new version (Save As). Moving a form is helpful if you want to delete a folder and keep the forms in that folder. 1. Open the Form in the Self Service Designer. 2. Click the **three-dot menu** in the Form tab and select **Edit**. 3. Within the **Folder** dropdown, select the new folder location. 4. Click **Save** to move the Form into the new folder.
chunks.originalContent:
It is possible to change the folder where a form resides without re-saving the Form as a new version (Save As). Moving a form is helpful if you want to delete a folder and keep the forms in that folder.

1. Open the Form in the Self Service Designer.
2. Click the **three-dot menu** in the Form tab and select **Edit**.  
3. Within the **Folder** dropdown, select the new folder location. 
4. Click **Save** to move the Form into the new folder.

chunks.content: **Activity Description:** Allows you to define multiple runtime inputs for a Self Service workflow. In the Self Service Portal, Activity Description can create a popup dialog where the user can be asked for multiple inputs at once during form execution. Each input definition is a field in the Self Service for dialog. **Output:** Result set table with two columns - the first column contains the input definitions, and the second one the user inputs. If no user input is available, the column will be empty. **Settings:** * **Input definition:** Free text and/or a variable (variable names must follow the convention [CODE_BLOCK]). Currently, up to ten entries are supported. :::note The Self Service form dialog will have the same timeout period as the one set for this activity. :::
chunks.originalContent:
**Activity Description:** Allows you to define multiple runtime inputs for a Self Service workflow. In the Self Service Portal, Activity Description can create a popup dialog where the user can be asked for multiple inputs at once during form execution. Each input definition is a field in the Self Service for dialog.

**Output:** Result set table with two columns - the first column contains the input definitions, and the second one the user inputs. If no user input is available, the column will be empty.

**Settings:**

* **Input definition:** Free text and/or a variable (variable names must follow the convention ```%Variable```).

Currently, up to ten entries are supported.

:::note

The Self Service form dialog will have the same timeout period as the one set for this activity.

:::

chunks.content: Setting permissions on a form will define who can access the Form in the Self Service portal. By default, Forms do not have defined permissions, which means Forms are available to everyone. Form permissions do not impact who can view or edit the Form in the Self Service Designer. Follow these instructions to add Form permissions. 1. Click the **Save As** icon in the top bar or the three dots in the Form tab. 2. Locate the **Permissions** table at the bottom of the Save As window, and choose the **Type** of **User** or **Group** in each row. 3. The **Name** field displays a list of all users/groups available in the **User Management** menu of Resolve Actions. 4. Select the appropriate users/groups based on your security requirements, and click **Save**.
chunks.originalContent:
Setting permissions on a form will define who can access the Form in the Self Service portal.

By default, Forms do not have defined permissions, which means Forms are available to everyone. Form permissions do not impact who can view or edit the Form in the Self Service Designer.

Follow these instructions to add Form permissions.

1. Click the **Save As** icon in the top bar or the three dots in the Form tab.
2. Locate the **Permissions** table at the bottom of the Save As window, and choose the **Type** of **User** or **Group** in each row.
3. The **Name** field displays a list of all users/groups available in the **User Management** menu of Resolve Actions.
4. Select the appropriate users/groups based on your security requirements, and click **Save**.

chunks.content: Making a self Service Form public is a convenient way to simplify access control, as it eliminates the need for User and Group permissions. A publicly published form is detectable by all forms of web agents who may seek to harm to your company. Use the following instructions to make a form public. 1. In the Self Service Designer, locate the **Control Panel**. 2. Check **Make Public**. 3. Review the **Public Form Disclaimer** before clicking **Accept**. - After accepting the disclaimer, a URL will appear under the "Make Public" checkbox. 4. Copy the URL to your clipboard. - Note: The URL is read-only.
chunks.originalContent:
Making a self Service Form public is a convenient way to simplify access control, as it eliminates the need for User and Group permissions. A publicly published form is detectable by all forms of web agents who may seek to harm to your company. 

Use the following instructions to make a form public. 

1. In the Self Service Designer, locate the **Control Panel**.
2. Check **Make Public**.
3. Review the **Public Form Disclaimer** before clicking **Accept**.
    - After accepting the disclaimer, a URL will appear under the "Make Public" checkbox.
4. Copy the URL to your clipboard.
   - Note: The URL is read-only.

chunks.content: To delete an activity: 1. Open the left drawer menu and navigate to the activity by hovering over **Category > Activity**. 2. Click the **trash can** icon that appears. 3. Confirm that you want to **permanently delete** the activity. A custom activity can be deleted only if it is **not used in any workflow**. First remove the activity from all workflows, and then delete it from the Activity Designer. To learn more about deleting categories, see *Deleting a Category* above. :::warning Deleted activities cannot be restored. :::
chunks.originalContent:
To delete an activity:

1. Open the left drawer menu and navigate to the activity by hovering over **Category > Activity**.
2. Click the **trash can** icon that appears.
3. Confirm that you want to **permanently delete** the activity.

A custom activity can be deleted only if it is **not used in any workflow**. First remove the activity from all workflows, and then delete it from the Activity Designer.

To learn more about deleting categories, see *Deleting a Category* above.
:::warning

Deleted activities cannot be restored.

:::

chunks.content: By default, all activities in a workflow are **enabled**, meaning they will run during workflow execution. While designing a workflow, you may want to disable specific activities to test portions of the workflow. To disable and enable an activity: 1. Locate the **toggle** on the left side of the activity. 2. To **disable** the activity, move the toggle to the **right**. A red dot appears, indicating that the activity is disabled. 3. To **enable** the activity, move the toggle to the **left**. The red dot disappears, and the activity becomes active.
chunks.originalContent:
By default, all activities in a workflow are **enabled**, meaning they will run during workflow execution. While designing a workflow, you may want to disable specific activities to test portions of the workflow.

To disable and enable an activity:

1. Locate the **toggle** on the left side of the activity.
2. To **disable** the activity, move the toggle to the **right**.
    A red dot appears, indicating that the activity is disabled.
3. To **enable** the activity, move the toggle to the **left**. 
    The red dot disappears, and the activity becomes active.

chunks.content: The **Paste** action lets you quickly move or duplicate activities within the same workflow or across different workflows. To paste an activity: 1. Click the **three-dot menu** in the upper-left corner of the activity you want to move or copy, then select: 1. **Cut** to move the activity, or 2. **Copy** to create a duplicate. 2. Go to the desired location and choose one of the following methods to paste: 1. Click the **three-dot** menu of the activity above your target location and select **Paste**. 2. Click the **node** where ou want to insert the activity. In the placeholder, that appears, click **Paste**.
chunks.originalContent:
The **Paste** action lets you quickly move or duplicate activities within the same workflow or across different workflows.

To paste an activity:
1. Click the **three-dot menu** in the upper-left corner of the activity you want to move or copy, then select:
   1. **Cut** to move the activity, or
   2. **Copy** to create a duplicate.
2. Go to the desired location and choose one of the following methods to paste:
   1. Click the **three-dot** menu of the activity above your target location and select **Paste**.
   2. Click the **node** where ou want to insert the activity. In the placeholder, that appears, click **Paste**.

chunks.content: Take these steps to create a new category: 1. Open the Activity Designer. 2. In the left navigation bar, click **+ New Category**. 3. In the **New Category** dialog box that appears, enter the category name. You can also create a new category from the New Activity Modal.

Take these steps to create a new category:

3. In the **New Category** dialog box that appears, enter the category name.

You can also create a new category from the New Activity Modal.

chunks.content: Subcategories are organized as folders within existing folders. Follow these steps after creating a category: 1. Open the Activity Designer. 2. In the left navigation bar, click **+ New Category**. 3. In the **Create Category** dialog box: 1. Enter the *Category Name.* 2. In *Create as a sub-folder of:* select the name of the parent folder.

3. In the **Create Category** dialog box:

chunks.content: To delete a category: 1. Open the left drawer menu and hover over the name of the category you want to delete. 2. Click the **trash can** icon that appears. 3. Confirm that you want to delete the category and **ALL** the activities within it. :::note If activities are assigned to a worfklow, you will not be able to delete the category. ::: For more information on deleting individual activities, see [LINK].
chunks.originalContent:
To delete a category:

1. Open the left drawer menu and hover over the name of the category you want to delete.
2. Click the **trash can** icon that appears. 
3. Confirm that you want to delete the category and **ALL** the activities within it.

:::note

If activities are assigned to a worfklow, you will not be able to delete the category.

:::

chunks.content: If you want to delete a category but keep its activities: 1. Open each activity and use the *Edit Metadata* option to move it to a different category. 2. Once all activities have been reassigned, follow the steps in [LINK] above. :::warning Deleted activities cannot be restored. :::

chunks.content: The Search tool lets you find activities by keyword. Results include both activity categories and specific activity types that match the search term. You can then select and add an activity directly from the results. [IMAGE] To add an activity using Search: 1. Hover over the **white node** where you want to add the activity. The white node becomes a **crosshair**. 2. Click the **crosshair** to add a placeholder. 3. In the Search field at the top of the placeholder, enter a search term. Matching categories and activities will appear as you type. 4. Click the **activity** that you want to add to the workflow.
chunks.originalContent:
The Search tool lets you find activities by keyword. Results include both activity categories and specific activity types that match the search term. You can then select and add an activity directly from the results. 

 ![Workflow Designer Add Activity via Search Tool](img/wd-add-activity-search.gif)

To add an activity using Search: 

1. Hover over the **white node** where you want to add the activity.
    The white node becomes a **crosshair**.  
2. Click the **crosshair** to add a placeholder.  
3. In the Search field at the top of the placeholder, enter a search term. Matching categories and activities will appear as you type.
4. Click the **activity** that you want to add to the workflow.

chunks.content: The Activities tree, in the upper-left corner of the Workflow Designer, lists all activity categories alphabetically. Each category shows: - A unique **icon** (left of the name) - A **color code** (left of the icon) - The **number of activities** in that category (right of the name) When an activity is added to a workflow, its category color appears in the upper-right corner of the activity element, helping you visually identify its origin. Many categories are divided into subcategories to organize large sets of activities by type. For example, the *Active Directory* category contains 30 activities grouped into subcategories like *Password Management*. [IMAGE]

- A unique **icon** (left of the name)
- A **color code** (left of the icon)
- The **number of activities** in that category (right of the name)

When an activity is added to a workflow, its category color appears in the upper-right corner of the activity element, helping you visually identify its origin.

Many categories are divided into subcategories to organize large sets of activities by type. For example, the *Active Directory* category contains 30 activities grouped into subcategories like *Password Management*.

chunks.content: To add an activity from the Activities tree: 1. Expand the category (and subcategory, if needed) to locate the activity. 2. Drag and drop the activity onto the canvas. 1. Hover over the activity until the crosshair cursor appears. 2. Drag it to a position marked by crosshair nodes [IMAGE]. [IMAGE] If placed incorrectly, simply drag the activity to the correct spot. 3. Configure the activity settings.
chunks.originalContent:
To add an activity from the Activities tree:

1. Expand the category (and subcategory, if needed) to locate the activity.
2. Drag and drop the activity onto the canvas.
   1. Hover over the activity until the crosshair cursor appears.
   2. Drag it to a position marked by crosshair nodes ![Crosshair](img/wd-crosshair.png).
    ![Workflow Designer Add_Activity_Draganddrop](img/wd-add-activity.gif)  
    If placed incorrectly, simply drag the activity to the correct spot.
3. Configure the activity settings.

chunks.content: The Suggested Activities list displays up to six recommended activity types based on the content of your workflow. Suggested Activities are context-sensitive, so the activity types that are shown vary according to the preceding activity. For example, after a **Send Email** activity, you may see suggestions like: [IMAGE] To add a suggested activity: 1. Hover over the white node where you want to add the activity. The white node becomes a crosshair. [IMAGE] 2. Click the crosshair. A placeholder for a new activity type is added to the workflow. [IMAGE] 3. Click **Suggested** to open the suggestions list. The Suggested Activities list opens. [IMAGE] 4. Select the desired activity to add it to the workflow.
chunks.originalContent:
The Suggested Activities list displays up to six recommended activity types based on the content of your workflow. Suggested Activities are context-sensitive, so the activity types that are shown vary according to the preceding activity.

For example, after a **Send Email** activity, you may see suggestions like:

![](img/1638e00506150d.png)

To add a suggested activity:

1.  Hover over the white node where you want to add the activity.  
    The white node becomes a crosshair.  
    ![Workflow Designer Add_Activity_Crosshair](img/1638e00504d0ea.png)
2.  Click the crosshair.  
    A placeholder for a new activity type is added to the workflow.  
    ![Workflow Designer New_Activity_Block](img/1638e0050536db.png)
3.  Click **Suggested** to open the suggestions list.   
    The Suggested Activities list opens.  
    ![Workflow Designer Suggested_Activities_List](img/1638e005068ab3.png)
4.  Select the desired activity to add it to the workflow.

chunks.content: The [LINK] is a web-based library of pre-built automations and integrations, designed to accelerate automation without scripting or coding. You can browse, search, download and import these assets into your environment. To download and use an activity: 1. Open the [LINK]. 2. Click **Resolve Actions**. 3. Find the activity: 1. Browse the list, 2. Use the *Search Automation Exchange* box. 4. Download the activity: * Clicking the Download icon in the *Actions* column left of the activity name; * Clicking on the activity name and then the **Download** button in the package detail window that appears. 5. [LINK] into VAR::PRODUCT. 6. Add it to your workflow as usual.
chunks.originalContent:
The [Resolve Automation Exchange](https://exchange.resolve.io/) is a web-based library of pre-built automations and integrations, designed to accelerate automation without scripting or coding. You can browse, search, download and import these assets into your environment.

To download and use an activity:

1. Open the [VAR::EXCHANGE](https://exchange.resolve.io/).
2. Click **Resolve Actions**.
3. Find the activity:
   1. Browse the list,
   2. Use the *Search Automation Exchange* box. 
4. Download the activity:
    * Clicking the Download icon in the *Actions* column left of the activity name;
    * Clicking on the activity name and then the **Download** button in the package detail window that appears.
5. [Import the activity](../../Activity-Designer/Importing-Activities.mdx) into VAR::PRODUCT.
6. Add it to your workflow as usual.
chunks.header: Importing Activities from the Automation Exchange
chunks.pageTitle: Importing Activities from the Automation Exchange

chunks.content: In the Workflow Designer, activities are the building blocks used to automate tasks. You can add activities in several ways, depending on your preferences and where the activity originates. This section outlines the available methods for adding activities to your workflow: - **From the Activities Tree** – Browse and drag activities from categorized lists. - **Using the Search Tool** – Quickly find and add activities by keyword. - **Using Suggested Activities** – Choose context-aware suggestions based on your workflow. - **Pasting Copied Activities** – Reuse activities from the same or another workflow. - **Importing from the Automation Exchange** – Add pre-built activities downloaded from the Resolve Automation Exchange. Each method supports flexible workflow creation, whether you're building from scratch, accelerating development with suggestions, or reusing existing logic. Explore the pages in this section to learn how to add activities using the approach that works best for your needs.
chunks.originalContent:
In the Workflow Designer, activities are the building blocks used to automate tasks. You can add activities in several ways, depending on your preferences and where the activity originates.

This section outlines the available methods for adding activities to your workflow:

- **From the Activities Tree** – Browse and drag activities from categorized lists.
- **Using the Search Tool** – Quickly find and add activities by keyword.
- **Using Suggested Activities** – Choose context-aware suggestions based on your workflow.
- **Pasting Copied Activities** – Reuse activities from the same or another workflow.
- **Importing from the Automation Exchange** – Add pre-built activities downloaded from the Resolve Automation Exchange.

Each method supports flexible workflow creation, whether you're building from scratch, accelerating development with suggestions, or reusing existing logic.

Explore the pages in this section to learn how to add activities using the approach that works best for your needs.

chunks.content: The ForEach control lets you repeat an activity or set of activities for each row in a table. When given a table of data, it automatically loops through each row and runs the defined activities. #### Inputs 1. **Table Variable**. The table you want to loop through written in the variable form of *%tableName%*. Tables can be memory tables, JSON objects, or derived from data mapping. A single column from the table can be specified using the variable format *%tableName.columnName%*. 2. **Output Variable Name**. This is the name used to reference the current row in the loop. Unique names are recommended if you plan to use multiple ForEach controls in the same workflow. The control will run once for each row in the table. For every iteration, the **Output Variable** will hold the current row's data. #### Supports Multiple Activities You can place any activities inside the ForEach control, and they will execute in sequence for each row. #### Additional Considerations If a table as no rows, the loop is skipped. Or if the specified variable is not a table, the loop is skipped. :::note The table is cached at the start of the loop and any changes made while the loop is running will not affect the current iteration. :::
chunks.originalContent:
The ForEach control lets you repeat an activity or set of activities for each row in a table. When given a table of data, it automatically loops through each row and runs the defined activities.

#### Inputs

1. **Table Variable**. The table you want to loop through written in the variable form of *%tableName%*. Tables can be memory tables, JSON objects, or derived from data mapping. A single column from the table can be specified using the variable format *%tableName.columnName%*. 
2. **Output Variable Name**. This is the name used to reference the current row in the loop. Unique names are recommended if you plan to use multiple ForEach controls in the same workflow. 

The control will run once for each row in the table. For every iteration, the **Output Variable** will hold the current row's data.

#### Supports Multiple Activities

You can place any activities inside the ForEach control, and they will execute in sequence for each row.

#### Additional Considerations

If a table as no rows, the loop is skipped. Or if the specified variable is not a table, the loop is skipped. 

:::note
The table is cached at the start of the loop and any changes made while the loop is running will not affect the current iteration.
:::

chunks.content: Redirects to another activity in the workflow (according to its name) and executes it. This activity is commonly used in cases of any failure (e.g., phone call establishment failure) to repeat the activity that failed to execute.
chunks.originalContent: Redirects to another activity in the workflow (according to its name) and executes it. This activity is commonly used in cases of any failure (e.g., phone call establishment failure) to repeat the activity that failed to execute.

chunks.content: * **Go to Activity** — The name of the activity instance in the workflow that the Goto activity redirects to. Example: `telnet1`
chunks.originalContent:
* **Go to Activity** — The name of the activity instance in the workflow that the Goto activity redirects to.  
  Example: `telnet1`

chunks.content: Executes one activity branch or another, according to a different activity's value or a system variable's value (e.g., Executes "Make Call" activity when a service fails to restart or continues regularly when restart attempts succeed). After an If-Else branch, the settings within the If-Else branch itself will show what the expected value of the If-Else branch will be. To add a branch to If-Else, click on the three dots in the root If-Else block and then click Add Branch.
chunks.originalContent: Executes one activity branch or another, according to a different activity's value or a system variable's value (e.g., Executes "Make Call" activity when a service fails to restart or continues regularly when restart attempts succeed). After an If-Else branch, the settings within the If-Else branch itself will show what the expected value of the If-Else branch will be. To add a branch to If-Else, click on the three dots in the root If-Else block and then click Add Branch.

chunks.content: * **Default Branch** – When none of the If-Else branch conditions apply, the one set as the default branch is selected (by default, the right branch is selected as the default branch). * **Type (Predefined/User Defined)**: * Predefined: predefined values that the activity might hold. Optional predefined values are: True, False, Success, Failure, Response, No Response. * User Defined: any value (e.g., textual, numeric) that the activity might hold. To use this option, select a condition type (and an operator) and type in the value it relates to. Optional operators are, for example: equals, contains. * **Condition Type** – When selecting a User Defined Type, select the condition type from the combo box. * **Value** – When selecting a Predefined Type, select the value from the combo box. For a User Defined Type, type it. * **Use Alternate Setting** – Determines whether to use an alternate setting, if required.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Default Branch** – When none of the If-Else branch conditions apply, the one set as the default branch is selected (by default, the right branch is selected as the default branch).
* **Type (Predefined/User Defined)**:
   * Predefined: predefined values that the activity might hold. Optional predefined values are: True, False, Success, Failure, Response, No Response.
   * User Defined: any value (e.g., textual, numeric) that the activity might hold. To use this option, select a condition type (and an operator) and type in the value it relates to. Optional operators are, for example: equals, contains.
* **Condition Type** – When selecting a User Defined Type, select the condition type from the combo box.
* **Value** – When selecting a Predefined Type, select the value from the combo box. For a User Defined Type, type it.
* **Use Alternate Setting** – Determines whether to use an alternate setting, if required.

chunks.content: Allocates a memory cell for a variable's numeric/textual value storage.

chunks.content: * **Memory Scope (Workflow/Global)** - Workflow: The variable is accessed only by this workflow. Global: The variable is accessed by all workflows. * **Variable Name** - The global variable's name (the name must differ from the activity's name). * **Variable Value** - The variable's initial value - a constant value or another variable (variable names must follow the convention `%Variable%`). * **Append** - The new value will be added to the existing one (relevant only for text values).
chunks.originalContent:
* **Memory Scope (Workflow/Global)** - Workflow: The variable is accessed only by this workflow. Global: The variable is accessed by all workflows.
* **Variable Name** - The global variable's name (the name must differ from the activity's name).
* **Variable Value** - The variable's initial value - a constant value or another variable (variable names must follow the convention `%Variable%`).
* **Append** - The new value will be added to the existing one (relevant only for text values).

chunks.content: * **Memory Scope (Workflow/Global)** - Workflow: The variable is accessed only by this workflow. Global: The variable is accessed by all workflows. * **Name** - The variable's name to be referenced (the name must differ from the activity's name). The name must start with a letter and contain only the A-Z, a-z, 0-9 characters. * **Value** - The variable's initial value - a constant value or another variable (variable names must follow the convention `%Variable%`). :::note Copy Excel Table Data You can paste data copied from Microsoft Excel to fill in the table in this activity. :::

* **Memory Scope (Workflow/Global)** - Workflow: The variable is accessed only by this workflow. Global: The variable is accessed by all workflows.
* **Name** - The variable's name to be referenced (the name must differ from the activity's name). The name must start with a letter and contain only the A-Z, a-z, 0-9 characters.

chunks.content: Executes two parallel activity branches or more. This activity is usually used when running two parallel workflows. To add a branch to Parallel, click on the three dots in the root Parallel block and then click Add Branch.
chunks.originalContent: Executes two parallel activity branches or more. This activity is usually used when running two parallel workflows. To add a branch to Parallel, click on the three dots in the root Parallel block and then click Add Branch.

chunks.content: Runs a child workflow within the current one. When running a few concurrent workflows, you can use a variable's value retrieved by a parallel workflow's activity. When doing so, make sure to use the value only after the activity has been performed; otherwise no value is retrieved. In addition, you can run the nested (child) workflow with variables, which is ideal when the variable in the parent workflow is dynamic – as is the case when running a loop – and those changes need to be captured and used in the child workflow as it runs in the background.
chunks.originalContent: Runs a child workflow within the current one. When running a few concurrent workflows, you can use a variable's value retrieved by a parallel workflow's activity. When doing so, make sure to use the value only after the activity has been performed; otherwise no value is retrieved. In addition, you can run the nested (child) workflow with variables, which is ideal when the variable in the parent workflow is dynamic – as is the case when running a loop – and those changes need to be captured and used in the child workflow as it runs in the background.

chunks.content: * **Workflow Name** - The child workflow to run (the name of the Run Workflow activity cannot be identical to the name of the workflow executed by the activity). * **Variables** - If desired, set variables to be used when the selected child workflow is executed. The **Name** is the variable's name to be referenced (the name must differ from the activity's name and must start with a letter and contain only the A-Z, a-z, 0-9 characters). The **Value** is the variable's value - a constant value or another variable (variable names must follow the convention `%Variable%`). Note that it is not possible to send both text and a variable in the same field (i.e., `getrowscount(%tablename%)`). :::note The variable passed to the child workflow is a copy of the variable in the parent workflow, meaning that changes made to the variable in the child workflow will not be reflected in the parent workflow. ::: * **Run in Background** – Check to run both workflows at the same time. Uncheck to wait for the parent workflow to wait for the child workflow's termination before continuing to the next activity.
chunks.originalContent:
* **Workflow Name** - The child workflow to run (the name of the Run Workflow activity cannot be identical to the name of the workflow executed by the activity).
* **Variables** - If desired, set variables to be used when the selected child workflow is executed. The **Name** is the variable's name to be referenced (the name must differ from the activity's name and must start with a letter and contain only the A-Z, a-z, 0-9 characters). The **Value** is the variable's value - a constant value or another variable (variable names must follow the convention `%Variable%`). Note that it is not possible to send both text and a variable in the same field (i.e., `getrowscount(%tablename%)`).  

:::note
The variable passed to the child workflow is a copy of the variable in the parent workflow, meaning that changes made to the variable in the child workflow will not be reflected in the parent workflow.
:::

* **Run in Background** – Check to run both workflows at the same time. Uncheck to wait for the parent workflow to wait for the child workflow's termination before continuing to the next activity.

chunks.content: Click the color-coded icon in the upper-right corner of an activity on the Workflow Designer canvas to open the **Details** dialog. [IMAGE] The **Details** dialog allows you to view and modify key activity parameters, such as implementation settings, timeouts, and error handling. The interface elements are: [IMAGE] 1. Activity type—Displays the name of the activity type. 2. Activity instance name—The user-defined name of the activity instance, referred to as **Activity Name** throughout VAR::PRODUCT and this documentation. 3. Activity instance name editor—Allows you to change the name of the activity instance. For details, refer to [LINK]. 4. Executor Module selection—Allows you to select the Executor module the activity will use. See [LINK]. 5. Timeout setting—Allows you to define the period of time after which the activity will automatically abort. For more information, refer to [LINK]. 6. Close—Closes the Details dialog without saving changes. 7. Settings—Allows you to configure implementation directions. Settings are displayed by default when the Activity Details dialog opens. 8. Error—Allows you to select error handling directions. For more information, refer to [LINK]. 9. Help—Displays more detailed information about the purpose of the activity and how to use it. 10. Note—Allows you to add free text comments. For details, refer to [LINK].
chunks.originalContent:
Click the color-coded icon in the upper-right corner of an activity on the Workflow Designer canvas to open the **Details** dialog.

![](img/wd-activity-details.png)

The **Details** dialog allows you to view and modify key activity parameters, such as implementation settings, timeouts, and error handling. The interface elements are:

![](img/wd-activity-details-features.png)

1. Activity type—Displays the name of the activity type.
2. Activity instance name—The user-defined name of the activity instance, referred to as **Activity Name** throughout VAR::PRODUCT and this documentation. 
3. Activity instance name editor—Allows you to change the name of the activity instance. For details, refer to [Updating the Activity Instance Name](./update-instance-name.mdx).
4. Executor Module selection—Allows you to select the Executor module the activity will use. See [Selecting an Executor Module](./select-executor-module.mdx).
5. Timeout setting—Allows you to define the period of time after which the activity will automatically abort. For more information, refer to [Setting the Activity Timeout](./set-activity-timeout.mdx).
6. Close—Closes the Details dialog without saving changes.
7. Settings—Allows you to configure implementation directions. Settings are displayed by default when the Activity Details dialog opens.
8. Error—Allows you to select error handling directions. For more information, refer to [Defining Error Handling](../../../Product-Navigation/Repository/General/Error-Handling.mdx).
9. Help—Displays more detailed information about the purpose of the activity and how to use it.
10. Note—Allows you to add free text comments. For details, refer to [Adding Notes](../../../Product-Navigation/Workflow-Designer/notes.mdx).

chunks.content: Executors improve workflow performance and scalability by providing load balancing among the servers. An executor can be made up of VAR::PRODUCT_FULL servers, third party servers, or both. To choose a specific executor for an activity: 1. In the **Activity Details** dialog, click the **branch-out icon** [IMAGE] 2. A list of all available executors appears. 3. Select the desire executor. 4. Click **Save** to apply the change. [IMAGE] :::note Selecting an executor is optional. If none is selected, the activity will use the default executor configuration. :::
chunks.originalContent:
Executors improve workflow performance and scalability by providing load balancing among the servers. An executor can be made up of VAR::PRODUCT_FULL servers, third party servers, or both.

To choose a specific executor for an activity:
1. In the **Activity Details** dialog, click the **branch-out icon**
 ![Executor.png](img/1638e005144503.png)
2. A list of all available executors appears. 
3. Select the desire executor.
4. Click **Save** to apply the change.

![Workflow Designer Activity Details Executor](img/1638e00514b0a5.png)

:::note
Selecting an executor is optional. If none is selected, the activity will use the default executor configuration.
:::

chunks.content: Each activity includes a **timeout setting**. If the activity does not complete within the defined time, it automatically aborts. The default timeout is one minute. To view or update the timeout: 1. Click the **clock icon**. [IMAGE] The current timeout value is shown in `hours:minutes:seconds` format. 2. Adjust the timeout value as needed. 3. Click **Save**. [IMAGE]
chunks.originalContent:
Each activity includes a **timeout setting**. If the activity does not complete within the defined time, it automatically aborts. The default timeout is one minute.

To view or update the timeout:
1. Click the **clock icon**.
![Activity Timeout](img/1638e005152f26.png)
The current timeout value is shown in `hours:minutes:seconds` format.
2. Adjust the timeout value as needed.
3. Click **Save**.

![Workflow Designer Activity Settings Timeout](img/1638e0051591ef.png)

chunks.content: At the top of the **Details** dialog, the strip displays: - The activity type on the left - The user-defined activity instance name on the right When you click over either item, a tooltip shows the full name, and an **Edit** icon appears next to the instance name. To update the name: 1. Click the **Edit** icon. 2. Enter the new name. 3. Click **Save** at the bottom of the dialog to apply the change. [IMAGE]
chunks.originalContent:
At the top of the **Details** dialog, the strip displays:
- The activity type on the left
- The user-defined activity instance name on the right

When you click over either item, a tooltip shows the full name, and an **Edit** icon appears next to the instance name.

To update the name:
1. Click the **Edit** icon.
2. Enter the new name.
3. Click **Save** at the bottom of the dialog to apply the change.

![](img/ax-edit-activity-instance-name.png)

chunks.content: Tags help organize and find workflows. You can use existing tags or create new ones. To create a new tag: 1. On the **Create New** screen, click **Add** next to **Tags**. 2. Enter the tag name and click **Add**. 3. Repeat as needed, then click **Save**. :::note Tags can be removed using the X icon or the **Clear all** button. You can also edit tags when saving the workflow. See [LINK].
chunks.originalContent:
Tags help organize and find workflows. You can use existing tags or create new ones.

To create a new tag:

1.  On the **Create New** screen, click **Add** next to **Tags**.  
2.  Enter the tag name and click **Add**.  
3.  Repeat as needed, then click **Save**.  
    :::note
    Tags can be removed using the X icon or the **Clear all** button. You can also edit tags when saving the workflow. See [Using the Save As Option](../../../Building-Your-Workflow/reviewing-and-sharing.mdx).

chunks.content: For convenience, you can create a Favorites list in the Workflow Designer, so you can quickly access the activities and controls that you use most frequently. To build a Favorites list: 1. From the Toolbox, hover over the relevant activity or control and click the star icon. The icon fills up and the resource is designated as a Favorite. 2. To view your Favorites list, at the top of the Activities list, click **My**. Your Favorites are listed in alphabetical order. 3. To remove a resource from the Favorites list, hover over the resource and click the star icon again. The selected resource is deleted from the Favorites list.
chunks.originalContent:
For convenience, you can create a Favorites list in the Workflow Designer, so you can quickly access the activities and controls that you use most frequently.

To build a Favorites list:

1. From the Toolbox, hover over the relevant activity or control and click the star icon.  

The icon fills up and the resource is designated as a Favorite.

2. To view your Favorites list, at the top of the Activities list, click **My**.  

Your Favorites are listed in alphabetical order.

3.  To remove a resource from the Favorites list, hover over the resource and click the star icon again.  

The selected resource is deleted from the Favorites list.

chunks.content: **Create New** adds a blank workflow with Start and End elements. To create a new workflow: 1. Click **Create New**. 2. Enter a logical, descriptive name in the **Workflow Name** field. If you enter a name that is already in use, the system will automatically save the workflow as `<name> (1)`. 3. Choose a **Folder** (default: **Workflows**). :::note You can create new folders. In the Repository section, see [LINK] 4. Add a **Description**. 5. Optionally, assign **Tags** to help organize and search workflows. See [LINK]. 6. Click **Create**. [IMAGE]
chunks.originalContent:
**Create New** adds a blank workflow with Start and End elements.

To create a new workflow:

1.  Click **Create New**.
2.  Enter a logical, descriptive name in the **Workflow Name** field.
    If you enter a name that is already in use, the system will automatically save the workflow as `<name> (1)`.
3.  Choose a **Folder** (default: **Workflows**).
    :::note
    You can create new folders. In the Repository section, see [Workflows](../../Repository/Workflows-and-Templates/Workflows.mdx)
4.  Add a **Description**.
5.  Optionally, assign **Tags** to help organize and search workflows.
    See [Adding Tags to a Workflow](./add-tags.mdx).
6.  Click **Create**.  
    ![Workflow Designer Canvas](img/wd-designer-canvas.png)

chunks.content: The Export feature lets you download a workflow in XML file format. Use this feature to review the XML structure, share the file with others, or keep a backup of the workflow.
chunks.originalContent: The Export feature lets you download a workflow in XML file format. Use this feature to review the XML structure, share the file with others, or keep a backup of the workflow.

chunks.content: The export can contain one or more workflows, stored as XML files named `<Workflow name>.xml`. In addition, each export contains a file named `workflows_export_summary.xml`. You can disregard this file when importing individual XML files. To export a workflow from the Workflow Designer: 1. Ensure that the workflow is opened in **Workflow Designer**. 2. On the left side of the workflow tab, click the three-dot menu and select **Export**. The workflow is exported to your local computer as a ZIP archive format. To export one or more workflows from Repository: 1. Go to **Main Menu > Repository > Workflows**. 2. Select one or more workflows in the list. 3. Click the **Export selected workflows** icon. The workflow is exported to your local computer as a ZIP archive format.
chunks.originalContent:
The export can contain one or more workflows, stored as XML files named `<Workflow name>.xml`. In addition, each export contains a file named `workflows_export_summary.xml`. You can disregard this file when importing individual XML files.

To export a workflow from the Workflow Designer:

1.  Ensure that the workflow is opened in **Workflow Designer**.
2.  On the left side of the workflow tab, click the three-dot menu and select **Export**.  
    The workflow is exported to your local computer as a ZIP archive format.

To export one or more workflows from Repository:

1.  Go to **Main Menu > Repository > Workflows**.
2.  Select one or more workflows in the list.
3.  Click the **Export selected workflows** icon.
    
    The workflow is exported to your local computer as a ZIP archive format.

chunks.content: You can import workflows saved as XM. :::note Export Format ZIP files contain one more more XML workflows and a `workflows_export_summary.xml` (which can be ignored). You can import the full ZIP or individual XML files. ::: To import: 1. Ensure the workflow has been exported in XML file format. 2. In **Open Workflow**, click **Import from file**. The standard operating system file opening dialog is displayed. 3. Selet the XML or ZIP file and click **Open**. :::note If a required module is missing, you'll be prompted to choose a replacement. One modules you have [LINK] to will be shown. ::: :::caution Importing a Workflow that contains an Integration Module (e.g., AWS) requires manually remapping activities to modules. Without manual remapping, you will receive an error: "Integration module is not ready." :::
chunks.originalContent:
You can import workflows saved as XM.

:::note Export Format
ZIP files contain one more more XML workflows and a `workflows_export_summary.xml` (which can be ignored). You can import the full ZIP or individual XML files.
:::

To import:

1.  Ensure the workflow has been exported in XML file format.
2.  In **Open Workflow**, click **Import from file**.  
    The standard operating system file opening dialog is displayed.
3.  Selet the XML or ZIP file and click **Open**.  
     
    :::note
    If a required module is missing, you'll be prompted to choose a replacement. 
    One modules you have [write permissions](../../../Product-Navigation/Configuration/Integrations-and-Modules/access-control-on-integrations-and-modules.mdx) to will be shown.
    :::

    :::caution
    Importing a Workflow that contains an Integration Module (e.g., AWS) requires manually remapping activities to modules. Without manual remapping, you will receive an error: "Integration module is not ready."
    :::

chunks.content: If the imported workflow already exists choose one of the following: 1. **Use existing** - Skip import and keep existing copy. 2. **Keep both** - Import under a new name (ending in `_Imported`). 3. **Overwrite** - Replace existing workflow.
chunks.originalContent:
If the imported workflow already exists choose one of the following:

1.  **Use existing** - Skip import and keep existing copy.
2.  **Keep both** - Import under a new name (ending in `_Imported`).
3.  **Overwrite** - Replace existing workflow.

chunks.content: To start using the Workflow Designer, open a workflow from the **Welcome** screen. [IMAGE] If no workflows are open when you log in, the **Welcome** screen appears by default. To open it manually, click the plus icon next to the workflow tabs. Available options: * **Create New:** Start with a blank worfklow. See [LINK]. * **Open Workflow:** Resume editing a saved workflow. See [LINK]. * **Templates:** Use a pre-built workflow as a starting point. See [LINK].
chunks.originalContent:
To start using the Workflow Designer, open a workflow from the **Welcome** screen.

![Workflow Designer Welcome](img/new-workflow.png)

If no workflows are open when you log in, the **Welcome** screen appears by default. To open it manually, click the plus icon next to the workflow tabs.

Available options:

*   **Create New:** Start with a blank worfklow. See [Creating a New Workflow](./create-new-workflow.mdx).
*   **Open Workflow:** Resume editing a saved workflow. See [Opening an Existing Workflow](#opening-an-existing-workflow).
*   **Templates:** Use a pre-built workflow as a starting point. See [Opening a Template](./open-template).

chunks.content: You can open saved workflows in three ways: * **Recent Workflows:** Use the **Welcome** screen. See [LINK] * **Repository:** Use the full list of saved workflows. See [LINK]. * **Import File:** From a previously exported XML file. See [LINK].
